This government remains firmly committed to Medicare, preserving it in full, including our commitment to bulk billing, which remains central to Medicare. We have no intention of weakening Medicare by the introduction of patient co-payments for bulk billed services.

answer.para: To ensure that the Australian public continues to have high level bulk billed access to GP services, this government, in the last budget, provided an additional $127 million to increase the scheduled fee for a GP attendance. The first instalment of this increase was introduced on 1 November 1998 with an additional increase provided on the first of this month. The government is engaged in negotiations with the medical profession on the possibility of a general practice financing agreement to further strengthen and modernise Medicare and so protect bulk billing into the future. The end of bulk billing, which we seem to have heard so much about lately, has clearly not arrived.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. If the minister thinks that there has not been a decline in bulk billing, can he confirm that the 1.6 per cent drop in bulk billing rates over the two years from 1996 to 1998 represents an extra 400,000 GP services a year for which patients have to pay out of their own pockets? I ask again: what action the government is taking to halt this decline?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam President, there is a false premise in the question from Senator Gibbs. The patients do not have to pay; they can go to another doctor who bulk bills. We have freedom of choice in this country. Patients may or may not wish to go. It is obvious that Senator Gibbs does not understand. In her own town of Ipswich there is probably a 90 per cent bulk billing rate. If you want a doctor who bulk bills and that is your wish, then you should go and find one.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. The one-third sale of Telstra delivered more than $1 billion through the Natural Heritage Trust and $250 million through the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund to regional and rural Australia. Minister, does the government remain committed to improving services in the bush and delivering an additional $671 million to rural and regional Australia from the sale of a further 16.6 per cent of Telstra? Is the minister aware of alternative policy proposals to the government's clear, consistent and up-front position on the sale of Telstra?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to both of Senator Tierney's questions is yes. Let me elaborate. The government remains committed to the further privatisation of Telstra because it will provide us with $671 million from the sale of the next 16 per cent, which we could use for a whole range of vitally important activities in rural and remote Australia. It will enable people in outer economic zones to have access to local calls for the first time and points of presence for the Internet so people can access the Internet at local call prices. People in remote and island communities will get decent community services for a change. The Natural Heritage Trust will get another $250 million. Black spots will be plugged in a number of major areas. There will be a television fund to expand SBS, and on it goes—rural transaction centres, continuous mobile phone coverage. All of these are conditional upon the further sale of Telstra.

answer.para: So what is the attitude of those who mindlessly oppose this? You only have to go back to 1994 when Mr Beazley said on Meet the Press, `I mean, you could privatise Telstra if you set your mind to it.' That is the problem. His mind has been in neutral ever since. He is basically a political and policy burnt out case. He is not interested in doing anything other than holding on. As Max Walsh said, he is simply another figurehead leader for the Labor Party. We know what happens when you have a vacuum. You get the likes of Mr Brereton getting up there trying to raise his profile. I commend Senator Faulkner for the bucket job he did on him in caucus recently. I thought it was very commendable for Senator Faulkner and Cheryl Kernot to take the position they did. But it is not good enough to do it behind closed doors. You have to get up there and spell out where you stand.

There are a few people who are prepared do this. Paul Keating came clean recently and said that there is no good reason to be owning telephone companies. The only problem is that when he was in government he did not take that line entirely, but the guy who sat there and knew that he was going to offer to sell Telstra to BHP was no doubt his deputy, Mr Beazley—the Deputy Prime Minister, the man who never was, the man who wants to pretend that you cannot see him in government, only in opposition.

One person who is really on the record in proposing an alternative approach is Senator George Campbell. Senator Campbell says, `We ought to consider breaking up Telstra into a number of separate identities.' That is what he is in favour of. Of course this is quite contrary to official policy, but Senator Campbell has not been rebuked. The reality is that Senator Campbell is also in favour of breaking up the Labor Party frontbench, presumably so they can install a few high impact facilities like himself. That is not a good enough substitute for policy. The approach to take is firstly to read the textbooks and find out what would happen if you actually broke it up. Your problem is that you listen to the trade union movement.

talk.start.para: —Senator Alston, do not address your answer across the chamber.

—Madam President, the trade union movement will not allow the further privatisation of Telstra, but they are more than happy to see it break up a bit because they know their members would not be affected by it. Once again, we have another wholly owned subsidiary of the movement in here, spruiking the union line but not in any shape or form being interested in policy.

answer.para: If Mr Beazley is fair dinkum about hanging on to the leadership, then he ought to abandon his policy, get serious, get out there and support this approach which, as you know, has momentum all around the country. Unfortunately, you cannot bring yourselves to do it. Even Senator Lundy, in the lead-up to the last election, said, `We will not entertain any structural separation of Telstra at this point in time.' In other words, they have an endlessly flexible approach. As soon as it suits them, they will be in like Flynn. Why not do it when it really matters? Why not look after regional and rural Australia? Why not get out there and provide the resources to do the job? (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Australian Medical Association Consultation

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator Herron. Can the minister explain why the government consulted private hospitals and health funds in preparing its Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) yet failed to consult the AMA? Is the minister aware that his own union, the AMA, has stated that it is simply beyond explanation that there was no consultation with any of the organised medical profession? Why is the AMA being punished by this government?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —As a former president of the Queensland division of the AMA, I find it interesting that it is now called a union. The AMA is certainly not a union; it is a voluntary organisation. All doctors actually belong to it—it is just that only about half of them pay their dues. There are a few benighted souls who meet in telephone boxes who are probably card carrying members of the ALP, such as members of the Doctors Reform Society. Having said that, whether or not the AMA was consulted is not terribly relevant because the government consults everybody. They even consulted members of the AMA who are members of the cabinet. And that is not me. As you know, I am not in cabinet. I am sure the minister was consulted. He has frequent meetings with the AMA, as Senator Evans well knows.

answer.para: I do not know which particular bodies the government consulted with. We are an inclusive government. We consult with everybody. There may or may not have been formal links with the AMA. I would be surprised if there were not consultations. I would never doubt that Senator Evans would tell us anything but the truth. If Senator Evans asserts that, I will ask the minister whether that was so and then get back to Senator Evans.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, but I do struggle to ask a supplementary after that. The point of the question went to why you did not consult the AMA. It is on the record that they were not consulted. Do the last minute changes that the government has now introduced to that bill reflect that you got it wrong the first time or is it that the minister is simply susceptible to last minute lobbying, as was the case with the MRI services? What are you about?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —We are about radical change in relation to health care in this country in that we are the government that introduced a 30 per cent rebate for private health insurance on 1 January. The Labor Party tried to destroy private health insurance. When Senator Evans asks me what we are about, the answer is that we are about freedom of choice. We are about allowing people the choice to take out private health insurance.

answer.para: The rebate is available to all Australians with Medicare eligibility who have an appropriate private health insurance policy provided by a registered health fund. The rebate can be received as a premium reduction through a private health fund, as a refundable tax offset, or as a direct payment from the Medicare office. That is significant. That is the most fundamental change that has been introduced within policy in this government. The Labor Party is a policy free zone. Where is the Labor Party's policy in health care? They have not got one. We are still waiting. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the minister aware that Employment National, a wholly government owned employment service provider, is abolishing maternity leave from its new workplace agreements and the safety net award? If so, what action has the minister taken, if any, or does she plan to take, to protect the working conditions of the approximately 60 per cent of Employment National staff who are women?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of that. I will certainly follow it up. As Senator Stott Despoja would no doubt be aware, the government has been very strong on encouraging workplace agreements where people can negotiate conditions for the conditions of service that appeal to them and that have high priority with them. What we have found at the end of the first year of operation of the workplace agreements is that, where there is a heavy predominance of women, family friendly workplace arrangements have increased and improved. So while I cannot say anything about Employment National, Senator, I will be very happy to have a look at that and see what sorts of arrangements were made to achieve that. I cannot answer you further on that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her commitment to chase that up but I ask if she will give the chamber another commitment, especially on this International Women's Day. Will the minister at least assure all women and all female workers that she will endeavour to ensure that maternity leave is considered a basic working condition to be present in all workplace agreements? Will she give us that commitment here and now?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I don't think Senator Stott Despoja listened as carefully as she might have. I said that the government believes that workplace agreements give workers and their employers the opportunity to negotiate for the conditions which are of most relevance to the workers in that particular workplace. I believe that is what most workers would want. They would want the choice themselves to determine what was their highest priority. I am not suggesting in any way that maternity—
—Most of the employees are men. What happens to the women in those workplaces?
—I am not suggesting in any way that maternity assistance is not important.
—Madam President, I take a point of order. For the record and for clarification, I only asked about female workers.
—There is no point of order.

—This government is very concerned to support pregnant women in the workplace. That is shown by the concern we have expressed over the need for an inquiry into discrimination against women who are pregnant. That is under way. If we were concerned to have pregnant women not in the workplace, Senator—if that is the implication behind your question—we would not have been pursuing that inquiry. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Transport. Can the minister confirm that Airservices Australia has written to Qantas, Ansett and the Sydney Airport Corporation attempting to offload its responsibility for managing Sydney Airport's Long Term Operating Plan? Is it a fact that the letter under signature of Mr Bill Pollard, the Chief Executive of Airservices Australia, cites flack over the plan and the resultant pressure as a reason for ditching their responsibility? Given that the letter imposes a deadline of 19 March so that a proposal can be presented to Minister Anderson, does the government support Airservices Australia's bid to shift their responsibilities to the Sydney Airport Corporation?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The first part of the question asked was I aware of that, and I must confess that the answer to that is no. I understand that a letter from the Chief Executive of Airservices Australia was sent to the Sydney Airport at the end of the week. Mr Pollard sets out some personal views, I understand, not his own. Airservices Australia has statutory responsibility for air traffic control. Was that the issue you were talking about, Senator?
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you should not be addressing remarks across the chamber.
—I am sorry, Madam President. The answer to the question the senator first asked is no, I am not aware of it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister is obviously clearly aware of the issue in that he referred to the letter from Mr Pollard, can he please answer the first question? While he is doing so, perhaps he could comment on Brendan Nelson's public comments. Was Brendan Nelson stating government policy when he slammed the idea as `preposterous' and `bizarre' and claimed that when he first saw the letter he thought it was a prank?
—I must confess that during the last week I was out meeting with local government and I didn't actually see what Dr Nelson said. He is a very distinguished member of parliament—
—And a former trade union official—President of the AMA.

—A former trade union official, is he? Does that mean that Senator George Campbell supports him? If he does, then Senator George Campbell would be supporting a very good member of parliament. But they are issues that the senator obviously is interested in and I will get from Mr Anderson a response to the question that Senator Mackay has raised.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. During hearings of the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Committee on a new tax system, we heard evidence that the reduction in diesel excise, planned in the government's tax package, will bankrupt oil recycling companies in South Australia and Western Australia. Given that the decimation of the oil recycling will mean that 149 million litres of oil per annum that is collected for recycling will be dumped in roads for dust control, dumped in pits or out in the bush or burnt in cement kilns or just dumped down the drain in our water system, has the minister any plans as to how these huge waste oil stocks will be handled? Has the minister considered the environmental impact of this possibility in his assessment of the tax reform package? Has the minister determined how much it is going to cost taxpayers to clean up this excess waste oil?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The issue of oil recycling has been one that we have been addressing even before consideration of the GST. It is an ongoing issue of environmental importance in this country. We would obviously like to find ways in which we could encourage the reuse of oil through recycling rather than see it end up where it has traditionally ended, and that has been in landfill.

answer.para: The honourable senator might be aware that there were changes made to avoid recycled oil being used as a diesel extender in a tax free way, and it is argued by the industry that this has had inadvertent consequences that have placed further pressure upon their industry when it actually refines the waste oil into a new product—something which we would seek to encourage. The government is addressing that matter that the industry has brought to its attention, and is looking at possible ways to assist, because the effect of the change—if restructuring the product in this way is putting pressure on industry—was inadvertent. It was not the government's intention that it would do so.

talk.start.para: —Oh, you got it wrong, did you?

—No, we did not get it wrong at all. It is a matter that is currently being addressed. The honourable senator might be aware that we have recently offered support for an initiative in the Northern Territory, where further effort is being made to look at new markets for recycled oil, and we will support other projects that can give greater opportunity for development of other market opportunities.

answer.para: Yes, it is an important issue, and I am pleased that Senator Margetts has picked it up. We will be looking at ways in which we can further encourage and support what is an important industry for not only economic reasons but also environmental reasons.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister mentioned that it is being addressed. Could the minister tell us when that information will be available? The minister would be aware that new markets are no good at all in Australia if the price mechanism precludes them. Given that the reduction in diesel excise has massive environmental impacts that will go well beyond the oil recycling industry—including increased air pollution; associated health impacts; increased greenhouse emissions of an estimated additional five million tonnes by 2010; disincentives for gas, solar and renewables, et cetera—will the minister comment on the fact that this tax reform proposal undermines key elements of the government's own program for reducing Australia's greenhouse gas emissions and contradicts recommendations of the National Inquiry into Urban Air Pollution and Australia's obligations under the framework convention on climate change? What is the government going to do to oppose the reduction in diesel excise in this tax package, as it is patently a disaster for the environment?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Madam President, the honourable senator has asked a second question in the form of a supplementary question. It is true that our tax reform package is designed in part to reduce the cost of transport fuel in Australia. We do not apologise for that, because we are interested in continuing to grow the economy and provide jobs. That is part of our win-win outcome. The other part of the win-win is that it can be done in an environmentally responsible way. What we are doing is implementing a range of programs to encourage and support renewable energy. There are a number of direct grant programs. We are establishing infrastructure for natural gas vehicles within Sydney, which we are going to extend to Melbourne. If I had the time, we could have a long debate on all the initiatives that this government has introduced to support the renewable energy industry, which is also vitally important to Australia's future.
—So why are they all cancelling contracts?
—They are not.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Non-Commercial Activities

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer.

question.para: Senator Knowles interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Have you stopped calling witnesses liars?

question.para: Senator Knowles interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Knowles, cease interjecting.
—Is the minister aware that in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 March, the Chief Commissioner of Guides Australia, Mandy Macky, stated:

question.para: Under the GST, these volunteers become tax agents for the government. When children bring in their weekly contribution of a few dollars, the leaders will need to put on their accountant's hat and skim off 10 per cent for the government.

If Ms Macky does not believe the minister's denials, why should the Australian public? Is it not the case that scouts and girl guides will, in fact, be tax collectors when they perform an activity that is equal to 50 per cent or more of the market value of an equivalent activity?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of the comment referred to by Senator Crowley. Of course, I would always read closely comments that are made by the scouts and the guides. They are bodies that are very much respected in this country and that, in my view, perform a very effective task. I point out to you, Senator, that the non-commercial activities of bodies such as scouts and guides will be GST free. Non-commercial activities will include supplies by such institutions for consideration of less than 50 per cent of GST inclusive market value. It is astonishing that you have raised this issue, because the Labor Party policy is to actually stop $13 billion of tax cuts to the Australian public, including the parents of scouts and guides. The Labor Party policy is to prevent real rises in pensions and benefits that we are trying to get through with our tax reform package. It is a great irony that you stand up here and intend to score a pathetic political point. We have made the issue quite clear on bob-a-job. I have made a statement on that matter.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know you do not believe me, Senator Cook. That is a great pity. I am awfully upset that you do not believe me, Senator Cook, I must confess. We have made the position clear. I underline the fact that Senator Crowley and her colleagues are trying to prevent—
—Didn't you see that letter? Did you understand it?
—Senators on my left, and on my right, will cease interjecting.

—I make the point that, in raising these issues, the public should be aware that Senator Crowley and her colleagues are trying to prevent some $13 billion of tax cuts—arguably the largest tax cuts in Australian history—being delivered to Australians, including the parents of scouts and guides.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you might get a profile of the parents of the scouts and guides with a conclusion that does not accord with what you say. Is it the case that the minister's denial that the GST would apply to bob-a-job week services applied strictly to activities performed during bob-a-job week? What about activities performed outside the bob-a-job week? Isn't it the case that, where scouts perform ongoing activities that are equal to more than 50 per cent of the market value of an equivalent service, these activities will attract the 10 per cent GST, as I understood you to just say, Minister?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Again I make the point that a bob-a-job activity is, as I understand it, a non-commercial activity and therefore is not subject to the GST. I have made that clear in my public statements. Commercial activities carried out by bodies are a different matter. Senator, you purport to raise concerns in this area, but the truth of the matter is that you are trying to deny huge tax cuts to the Australian public, including the parents of scouts and guides. That is what you are trying to do. Your standing up here and pretending to weep tears over this issue is pathetic.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Today, on International Women's Day, will the minister advise the Senate of the initiatives and achievements of the government in the area of women?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Despite the noise coming from the opposition benches, International Women's Day is a very important day. It gives us the opportunity to reflect on the advances in the lives of women in Australia. I was disappointed that I think only the Leader of the Opposition managed to tear himself away from the parliament to go and recognise the achievements of previous generations of women at the War Memorial today. I also announced today an extension of the government's executive search pilot program and the early warning system, which are initiatives aimed at increasing the number of women appointed to Commonwealth boards and committees. Only last week the government reported to the UN in New York about a series of initiatives and successes—
—Why don't you front up to the OSW estimates?
—Senator Faulkner, there is an appropriate time to raise that matter.

—Madam President, the Leader of the Opposition sledges and shouts every time I get up to speak. How much longer do I have to put up with his noise? Australia has one of the healthiest populations in the world and high life expec tancies. Despite the opposition's lack of interest, let me tell those who would listen and the media what we have done.

answer.para: We have introduced the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate, which is terribly important to a lot of women with families or older women with illnesses; screening services to detect breast and cervical cancers; increased breast cancer research funding; education strategies on the benefits of folate for the prevention of spina bifida in children—we were talking about pregnant women earlier, and this is a very important initiative; the maternity allowance initiative through the social security system; encouragement for families to immunise their children—this is terribly important for the girl child when you think of the danger of measles, for example; campaigns targeted to preventing domestic violence, such as the $25 million partnership against domestic violence; the fly-in fly-out female GP services for women in rural and remote areas who do not have access to a woman doctor; and the all-important Medicare program and the pharmaceutical benefits program. That statement I am advised was received very well and with great interest in New York by the delegations who were there at the UN.

Let me also remind the Senate of the $1 billion family tax initiative when we first came into government that supports women's choice as to when and whether they are in the work force totally, only in part or at home while the children are young. The government's tax reforms will be building on that initiative. The coalition will be spending $24 million over four years on a return to work initiative for those who are returning to the work force after an absence of two or more years. That is primarily women who have been in a caring role for either children or relatives and they come back with a loss of skills, a loss of confidence and a need for assistance.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The government's spends over $1 billion a year on child care. In the last year of the Labor government they spent $875 million.
—Madam President, things are unruly, and this constant shouting makes it impossible. This is a serious answer to a serious question, and a little courtesy from the other side would be appreciated.

—Madam President, on a point of order: first of all, Senator Hill just stood up and did not take a point of order. Even when he did stand up and address the chair, quite improperly in that regard, it was a hypocritical load of claptrap.

—There have been far too many interjections today. It is very difficult to hear question time, and I imagine it is difficult for those listening on radio to hear as well. Reasonable interjections from time to time can be tolerated, but there has been a great deal of shouting and sledging going on during question time today.

—The opposition would put misinformation about because it hates the public hearing the truth. But the Senate child-care inquiry, which involved all parties of course, has supported the government's main changes.
—Why don't you go to OSW estimates?
—Senator Faulkner, stop interjecting!

—Tax reform will also add extra assistance to families with child-care assistance. Those opposite would hate to hear about the extra places that have been provided and the extra money that has been spent in child care since they were in government, but they are the facts. That is the truth. The Workplace Relations Act provides increased opportunities to balance work and family responsibilities. The first Workplace Relations Act report in October last year showed that female workplaces are more likely to have the family leave provisions.
—What! What about Employment National?
—Order! Senator Carr and other senators on my left will cease shouting!
—Madam President, at the very least I would have thought the Labor women would have been glad to listen to the advances that have been provided for women in Australia. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I believe the minister has reflected on honourable senators. I for one had accepted an invitation to go to the War Memorial but had to cancel because I then heard that I had to make a speech on workplace relations before lunch.
—That is a matter of personal explanation rather than a point of order, Senator.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister further expand on the Howard government's successes and achievements for women, particularly in respect of the new jobs that have been created for women in Australia and also in terms of domestic violence prevention programs?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The job situation for women in Australia is one of the best success stories of the Howard government's first three years. Women's unemployment is 7.2 per cent, the lowest rate since 1990—and all the noise from the other side of the chamber will not hide that. The labour force participation rate for all women remains high at 53.7 per cent in January 1999. The labour force participation rate for women with children under the age of 15 has been consistent at around 59 per cent for the past three years. The Workplace Relations Act has removed restrictions on women's access to permanent part-time work. Jenny Macklin, the shadow minister for the status women, has claimed that women's wages need to be protected. She is clutching at straws. In August last year, women's average hourly earnings were 87.5 per cent of men's, an increase over the 86.3 per cent prior to the commencement of the Workplace Relations Act. In the 12 months ending November last year, women's full-time adult earnings—(Time expired)

—My question without notice is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of the concerns expressed by the Victorian education minister, Mr Honeywood, that the establishment of the new private university, Greenwich, on Norfolk Island late last year has serious implications for the quality and reputation of Australian university education? How does the minister respond to the charge by Mr Honeywood that the federal government has turned a blind eye to its duty of care to ensure that the same scrutiny of curriculum standards in mainland Australia is applied to Greenwich? Can the minister confirm the chancellor of Greenwich's claim that `the approval was given by the Commonwealth to proceed with the university in December 1997'?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —In relation to Greenwich University, I can advise the Senate that it has now changed its own description on its web site from `fully accredited' to `self-accrediting'. Governmental recognition is being sought on behalf of the university by the Norfolk Island minister responsible for higher education. In late January, he wrote to the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs seeking MCEETYA's agreement to include Greenwich University on the Australian qualifications framework register of bodies authorised to accredit Australian courses of study and issue Australian qualifications. These registers are the policy instrument by which Australian governments vouch for the quality of Australia's higher education and training system.

answer.para: I understand that the minister for education has instructed the department to undertake a rigorous examination of Greenwich University to assist him in forming a view on the minister's request to include Greenwich University in the AQF registers. The department has also flagged the minister's intention to invite the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and also state and territory colleagues to consider this and other relevant information before forming a view on the matter.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can I infer from the Minister's answer that he is in fact confirming a response from Mr Honeywood that the government has turned a blind eye to its duty of care to ensure the quality of Australian education? Can the minister confirm that the only contact between DETYA and the territory's office before the minister for the territory approved the legislation creating Greenwich University occurred in December 1997? Can the minister also inform the Senate whether claims by the chancellor of Greenwich University that the university was examined and approved by DETYA in 1997 and 1998 are true?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —What I said in my previous answer was that the government indeed was not turning a blind eye to this issue. In fact, the minister concerned had initiated a rigorous examination of the university concerned. This matter is going to be canvassed at MCEETYA in great detail, and the government is taking it seriously.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Can the minister confirm that senior bureaucrat Mr Howard Bamsey is about to head off on another world trip to prop up the government's Jabiluka mine decision? Can he confirm that Mr Bamsey is going to the UK, Italy, Switzerland and the United States, and is it not the case that he has already been to the US on Jabiluka within the last eight weeks? Can the minister confirm that his mission is to persuade industry to pressure their governments leading up to the world heritage vote this year? Will Mr Bamsey also be admitting that traditional owner Yvonne Margarula is facing a gaol sentence for walking on her own land? Can the minister advise the Senate how much Mr Bamsey's trips are costing the Australian taxpayers and how long he will be spending out of the country in total on this mission?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I will get details of Mr Bamsey's travel program for the honourable senator. As the honourable senator will know, he is a highly respected former ambassador for the environment. He certainly would not be going overseas to `prop up' the government's position on Jabiluka. It does not need propping up. All we need to do is have the opportunity to convey the true facts—not undermined by the mischief of the Australian Democrats—to parties that are members of the World Heritage Committee and seek an objective judgment and a fair assessment. There will be no alternative but to dismiss this nonsense idea of putting the world heritage area in the endangered category.

answer.para: As to the reference to Yvonne Margarula, it would have been more accurate to say that she is facing a penalty for a conviction that has occurred. In relation to the cost of any travel, I will get that, but I have said to the Senate before that we estimate the cost of defending the government's case in relation to Jabiluka will be in the vicinity of $1 million. That is money which we would have much preferred to put into world heritage conservation and management but, unfortunately, largely through the actions of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, we have had to spend it on these other causes of less value.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister says that Mr Bamsey is going overseas to carry the truth. The minister also said that some time ago a report was being developed which would have such truths in it. My question then to the minister is: when will this report be available? Did the minister also know that Yvonne Margarula has now appealed against that gaol sentence for walking on her own land and that Jaqui Katona and Christine Christopherson have spent time in the Berrima gaol? Why is the minister still engaging in these international dirty tricks by sending public servants overseas?
—Senator Allison, I ask you to rephrase your question and not reflect upon the minister in that fashion.
—If I can ask then, Madam President, how many more public servants will be—
—Senator Allison, you should not leave your question in that fashion.

—I withdraw that part of my question and ask: how many more public servants will be sent overseas to undermine the integrity of the world heritage convention? Wouldn't it save us a lot of money, time and face if we just let the World Heritage Committee make up their own minds—(Time expired)

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —What the honourable senator is saying is that they should make up their own minds on the misinformation provided by her and her party. No, we do not believe that is the right way. We want the truth put to the committee so they can then make a decision objectively and fairly.

answer.para: We actually want to protect the integrity of the world heritage system from being undermined by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. For 18 years, the Australian Labor Party stood by the Ranger mine and did not suggest once that it threatened the world heritage values of Kakadu—not once. As soon as they were thrown out of government, they thought that, yes, a much smaller, more modern underground mine means the whole of the park should be labelled as in danger. What a nonsense. It is that sort of nonsense that we are seeking to correct. We are preparing the consultation reports that were requested by the World Heritage Committee in Kyoto. When they are available, we will make a copy available to the honourable senator.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Does the minister agree with Mr Honeywood, the Victorian education minister, that the Commonwealth government has turned a blind eye in its duty of care to ensure that the same scrutiny of curriculum standards that apply on mainland Australia are applied to Greenwich University on Norfolk Island? Why did the minister—again, according to Mr Honeywood—fail to apply pressure on the Norfolk Island administration to do the right thing and allow it to choose unilaterally to go ahead and authorise tertiary education providers that do not have a track record in Australia, even if they have miraculously changed their web site in the last two weeks? Given that Senator Ellison has now revealed that the government has undertaken a rigorous examination of Greenwich University, does the minister now accept that his statement in estimates that `all legislation of Norfolk Island only affects Norfolk Island' was ignorant, inaccurate and dangerous?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Mackay obviously was asleep while Senator Carr was asking his question. I do not blame her, I might say. Senator Ellison has answered that question already, and I do not know that I can add a great deal more.

answer.para: I do want to emphasise to Senator Mackay—as I did at estimates—that the Greenwich University is set up under Norfolk Island legislation. In case Senator Mackay does not know—and she should know, because I think she shadows me on territories—the Norfolk Island government is a self-governing government of the self-governing territory of Norfolk Island and it has responsibility for higher education in the same way as, for example, the University of Notre Dame is the responsibility of the Western Australian minister for higher education. The Norfolk Island minister for higher education has the responsibility for that.
Senator Carr, as I understand it, mentioned a number of matters that happened in 1997. I have to say that, regrettably, I was not the minister at the time so I have no personal knowledge of that.

talk.start.para: —You signed it off, though.

—Not in 1997, I did not. I was not in the ministry in 1997, unfortunately. I do underline the fact that the university may not operate as a university on mainland Australia and that the bona fides and standards of the Greenwich University are essentially a matter for the territory's government. As my colleague has mentioned—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The application has been made by the territory government and the ministerial council on education—what is it called?
—MCEETYA.
—It has been referred to MCEETYA and the universities will consider all of these matters. I cannot add much more to the answer that Senator Ellison has already given.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister prefer that in future we ask our questions as multiple choice? When the minister approved the creation of Greenwich University, was he aware that the Victorian government had raised concerns about this same university in 1993? Given Minister Ellison's answer to Senator Carr that a rigorous examination would be taking place, what steps did the minister take before approving the creation of the university to assure himself that it would not create problems in other jurisdictions?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thought that was pretty funny, Senator Mackay, but my colleagues did not appreciate your humour. I also thought a lot of your press releases that came out of the estimates committee hearings were pretty funny as well. I regret from your point of view that you did not get much of a run on them. Senator Ellison has answered the question very fully and fairly—
—And eloquently.

—And eloquently. I emphasise again that higher education and the question of the Greenwich University setting up on Norfolk Island is a matter for the Norfolk Island government. When the matter was raised with my department, we made all the usual inquiries and spoke with the Norfolk Island government about it. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Our government has shown a strong commitment to indigenous affairs with a record $1.9 billion in spending this financial year. Given that today is International Women's Day, what is our government doing to promote the safety and wellbeing of women, particularly indigenous women, in remote communities?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for the question because I know of her own interest in indigenous affairs and the fact that she is convening two meetings in the next few weeks in relation to this issue. I also listened with interest to the response given by Senator Newman to the question from Senator Synon. It is important, as Senator Newman mentioned, that we make progress in other matters as we approach the new millennium. It is important to reflect on progress that the government has made in the area of family violence and to think about what still needs to be done.

answer.para: It is of grave concern to me that, around the country and particularly in remote areas, some indigenous women continue to experience appalling levels of physical and psychological abuse. It is absolutely unacceptable for women and children to live their lives in such threatening and dangerous circumstances. A determined effort is required. That is why next month I will convene a round table conference of key indigenous groups, health organisations and government officials to canvass ways of stopping family violence in indigenous communities.

It is important that we consult women and men directly about this issue. It must be remembered that this is predominantly a men's issue. Women and children are the victims. From my discussion with community leaders, there is support for mandatory counselling of those convicted of family violence abuse against women and children in the same way that sex offenders receive mandatory counselling.

Another area which needs to be explored is the option of removing offenders from family homes rather than the victims who are often forced to flee to women's shelters for protection. We need renewed thinking about this. It is absurd that we take the women and children out of these situations, put them in refuges and leave the men there in the home—in many cases contributing to destruction in the homes. That is why we should be making it easier for the victims and also preserving the housing stock which in many cases can be damaged by an angry abuser.

Finally, indigenous communities themselves can and must take action to control the sale and use of alcohol because violent men and alcohol is a dreadful combination. In turn, we need the communities to take control. The existing indigenous community organisations, including the Aboriginal Legal Service, must do everything within their power to assist and defend the women. There is obviously a role for state governments and communities themselves in terms of licensing, policing, counselling and intervention services. While the Commonwealth does not have a primary role in this area, if there are effective strategies which we can implement to help make these communities safe, then we should do so as a matter of priority.

I am currently taking stock of all the programs the Commonwealth has in place to prevent family violence in indigenous communities and to help the victims of family violence. In particular I have asked ATSIC, as the responsible agency in my portfolio, to give close attention to the ways in which it can address family violence. I want to see a range of coordinated government programs that tackle the issue in indigenous communities. To this end, I will be raising the issue with my state and territory colleagues at the next ministerial council meeting to determine how different levels of government can work together effectively to target those most in need.

In 1997 the Prime Minister convened the National Domestic Violence Summit at which heads of government agreed to work together in partnership against domestic violence to find better ways to prevent family violence across Australia. As Senator Newman stated, the government provided $25 million for this initiative and has since made a commitment to contribute another $25 million. I will be focusing on rural and remote areas to ensure that indigenous women and children more readily receive assistance. This year I want family violence to be a high priority issue.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

Senator HERRON

talk.start.para: —During question time, Senator Evans asked me a question about the involvement of the AMA. Madam President, I would draw your attention to the Senate legislation committee hearings on 17 February when Senator Chris Evans said:

We did consult the AMA, and the AMA policy officer has, in discussions with us, apologised for the fact that he said they were not consulted.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I have answers to two questions which I took on notice, and which I will seek to have incorporated. The first was from Senator West regarding the role of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in a women in leadership seminar. The second was from Senator Bishop in relation to tracking polling conducted in relation to the government's tax information campaign.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE AND MINISTER REPRESENTING THE PRIME MINISTER SENATE QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE

On Thursday, 18 February 1999 (Hansard page 2109) Senator West asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister and Leader of the Government in the Senate, about the role of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in the women in leadership seminars being held in Sydney on 25 March 1999, and about the nature of the support the Department is providing for the seminars.
I have sought the Prime Minister's advice and the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

"The seminar series, Women in Leadership—Public Sector Governance, has been developed by executive search firm Profile Ray & Berndtson to provide a range of information for those interested in serving on Commonwealth boards and to educate public servants involved in Commonwealth board appointment processes. The Office of the Status of Women (OSW) within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has provided advice on possible seminar topics, venues and a range of potential speakers. Costs to OSW for this have been limited to staff time. OSW has also given in-principle agreement to help publicise the seminars through its networks as the seminars complement other initiatives underway aimed at encouraging an increase in the number of women in decision-making positions. Through an oversight, the initial advertising of these seminars was inadvertently published by Profile Ray & Berndtson without OSW's authorisation. OSW has requested that further advertising by Profile Ray & Berndtson clarify that OSW is only a co-sponsor of this initiative. Conduct of the seminars, their timing and final selection of speakers are a matter for the company concerned."
I refer to a question from Senator Bishop on 16 February asking who had access to the tracking polling conducted with the government's tax information campaign.

I have made inquiries and have been assured that access to the polling results was confined to those persons in government who had a legitimate right to know whether the campaign was succeeding in its aim of successfully informing the community of the tax reform proposals.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Non-Commercial Activities

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crowley today, relating to the impact of a proposed goods and services tax on the guide and scout movements.

The boy scouts and girl guides associations of Australia should be prepared to be patronised and misled by this government. The Taxation Institute of Australia, a body that represents all the tax experts in this nation, said to the Senate inquiry into the GST just last week that, even if you believed in a GST, the operative date for the new legislation should be deferred for at least six to 12 months because there are too many devils in the detail. We have been told about the headlines; the experts have looked at the detail, found too many flaws and said that, even if you believe it, it should be put back.

An example of why it should be put back is one of the devils in the detail that affects boy scouts and girl guides in this nation. There are over 100,000 boy scouts and girl guides in Australia. They learn self-reliance, resourcefulness, community service and bush craft, and you do not find them in the juvenile courts. These are young kids in this country carving out a more sustainable and self-reliant lifestyle for themselves and they are not juvenile offenders. This is a very positive community based activity for young teenagers in this country.

But what do we discover? We discover that the GST will tax their activities. If you go to a camp, you will pay a 10 per cent GST on top of the service provided by the scouting masters in providing that camp. And, if you are out there collecting a bob-a-job, you will pay in certain circumstances a 10 per cent GST on bob-a-job.
Let me illustrate that. This is a letter from the office of the Assistant Treasurer to the scouting organisations of Australia. They say in the concluding paragraph:

During jobs week, scouts appear to be acting on behalf of Scouts Australia, as any payment goes to Scouts Australia. These activities are taxable in the same manner as if they were provided by a private sector organisation.

That is a letter from the Assistant Treasurer. When that became public, the Assistant Treasurer rushed out and had a doorstop and breathlessly told the Australian media there assembled, `But hang on, it doesn't apply to non-commercial activities.' He has repeated that line again today and let us get it right.

Among the 16 bills this government has presented to the parliament is legislation which deals with non-commercial activities by organisations such as the scouts and the girl guides. This means that, if a boy scout cuts someone's lawn and the commercial rate from Jim's Mowing is $50 a week, for example, and you donate to that scout for doing that same job—the non-commercial job—more than half the cost, that is $25.01, then the scouts pay 10 per cent GST on that cost. If a boy scout or a girl guide cleans someone's car, and the cost of the nearest commercially located car cleaning operation is $30, and you donate to the scout or the girl guide more than $15, a 10 per cent GST is payable.

What the government has not told the scouts and guides, and what the government has misled the public about, is that there is in fact this test about non-commercial ability in the legislation. The test goes to activities that are equal to more than 50 per cent of the market value of an equivalent service. These activities will then attract a 10 per cent GST. What do we have from the minister? A totally misleading piece of information.

talk.start.para: —He misled the Australian people.

—The girl guides and boy scouts organisations in Australia are not revolutionary organisations; they are made up of children of solid citizens of this country and command respect from everybody. This government has misled them. They do not believe this government. After the minister having come out and said what he did, the girl guides wrote to the Sydney Morning Herald on 2 March—and here is a copy of the letter—and said, among other things:

speech.para: Under the GST these volunteers become tax agents for the government. When children bring in their weekly contributions of a few dollars, the leaders need to put on their accountant's hat and skim off 10 per cent for the government.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I find this debate on the taking note of an answer given by Senator Kemp during question time today really interesting. I think it is the first time ever I have heard the opposition mention the scouts or the guides. I just want to bring Senator Cook up to date: they are no longer called girl guides; they changed their name some time ago to the Guide Association of Australia. But he would not know that. He talked about scouting masters, not scout leaders—
—I was a scout; I was not a guide.
—It is a shame they did not teach you more.

speech.para: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —A senator just interjected with, `There weren't delinquents in the scouts.' But I am sure you were an exception to that rule, Senator Cook.

speech.para: What the parents of scouts and guides have been subjected to over the years is a ramshackle wholesale sales tax system. We do not hear those on the other side saying that the parents of scouts and guides, many of them middle and low income earners who, in fact, have been subjected to high income tax rates, now will in fact see tax cuts. We have not heard them talk about the fact that the parents of scouts and guides now, currently, are seeing in their pockets, because of reduced interest rates, higher family income enabling them to actually support some of the activities that the scouts and guides participate in.

But individual scouts and guides currently pay wholesale sales tax on individual purchases they make, such as tents, camping equipment, boots, and everything else they might use—and you stand in here and say that they will pay GST on their bob-a-job! Let me say to you: it has been a long time since anything called `bob-a-job' was done, and it is not called that any more. I do not think you would find a kid who does a chore who gets anything like 50 per cent of its commercial value. The whole aim of that activity was to teach young people to be self-reliant, not to ask for handouts.

I was reared in this tradition and I am still a part of it. I must state a conflict of interest in this debate: I am a member of the State Council of the Guide Association of Victoria, and I have been a member since I was 10 years of age. Members in that organisation are taught self-reliance, not to ask for handouts, not to ask and beg; they are taught to work for what they earn—a mutual obligation. That is what the association is on about.

talk.start.para: —And then they pay tax on it.

—But young people who undertake to do a chore do not get 50 per cent of its commercial value. If somebody makes a donation to the scouts organisation or the guides organisation itself, that donation is tax deductible.
—Not to the scout or the guide.
—Order! Senator Cook.
—Very few of those young people ever would receive 50 per cent of the real commercial rate for a chore they would do.
—They would often receive more.

—I have to say that, looking at the ramshackle system that Labor left us with, looking at that totally incomprehensible system—a system where you have a scout or a guide paying wholesale sales tax on strawberry Quik and not on chocolate Quik—I find it incredible that those opposite would even try to get up here and defend it. It is a taxation system which is outmoded, outdated and outrageous.

speech.para: What we want to do for scouts and guides, and all young people in Australia, is to provide them with a future; provide them with a tax system which will take them into the next millennium, which will serve them well in ensuring that the states have sufficient revenue to deliver services. These are the issues we are concerned about—not nitpicking at little tiny things which need addressing.

talk.start.para: —They say that the organisations will go down the drain. They do. Read their letter.
—Senator Cook says that the organisations will go down the drain. I have to say to you that I would have preferred the association to come to us directly, to speak to us and have the thing clarified.
—You wrote the letter.
—I did not write the letter.
—Senator Kemp's office sent them the letter.
—Order on my left!

—What I am saying is that the wholesale sales tax system and the tax system to which all young people are subjected now is outmoded, outdated and irrelevant. We are going to put a tax system in place that is more relevant to young people in Australia than the outdated, outmoded tax system that we inherited from you.

—What we have seen in this example from the scouts and guides associations is another expose of the government having misled the Australian people. We have seen the government go to an election with $20 million worth of advertising before it and fail to mention the following fact: there are no jobs in the package. It is acknowledged by all the modellers that there are no jobs in the GST.
—There are 30,000 jobs.
—Order! Senator Ferguson.

—There are no jobs in the GST. What we have seen is Treasury refuse to do any analysis. Treasury knows that, if it does some analysis of the tax package, it will blow the government out of the water. The way that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have misled this debate has been a disgrace. We have had the government claiming that there are jobs. We have had the government claiming there is an improvement in national savings. That is another furphy.

speech.para: There is no modelling whatsoever by Treasury to support it, no modelling at all. Why? Treasury officers had to admit in front of estimates the other day that they know that this tax package will lead to a reduction in national savings. The Prime Minister proudly claimed during the election that there would be no short-term job losses. That is what he said—no short-term job losses. When we get the Prime Minister's preferred modeller, Chris Murphy, the Liberal Party stooge, up in front of the committee, what happens? He has to admit—

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I had thought, Madam Deputy President, that you might have drawn Senator Conroy's attention to his language. But I think he should be made to withdraw the slight he made on a professional person by calling him a stooge in this chamber—any more than we would call Professor Dixon a Labor Party stooge.
—There is no point of order.

—The Liberal Party stooge, Chris Murphy, comes before the committee and has to admit that, on his modelling—the Prime Minister's preferred modelling—there will be short-term job losses. Where was Chris Murphy during the election, you might ask? He had to admit that jobs in Queensland, jobs in Tasmania, jobs in the tourism industry, jobs in the housing industry and, last week, jobs in the book industry will all be lost.

speech.para: What happened during the election? He was out there supporting the Prime Minister, trying to pretend otherwise. He issued a press statement during the election claiming the benefits of the GST package. And, accidentally, what fell off the side of his paper that he prepared earlier was the potential job losses. It was there in his original modelling that he issued around the country and he says he publicised well. But during the election campaign when the pressure was on he issued a press statement that did not mention the job losses that were there in his earlier modelling.

The beef industry came out last week and said, `We are a bit worried about the impact on beef. We think the National Farmers Federation are out of touch. We think the National Farmers Federation support for this package shows they are not in touch with their own constituency because the impact in the beef industry is going to be negative.' The banana industry came out last week and said, `We think the impact is going to be negative.' But, worse, we had Mr Symond from Aussie Home Loans really blow the issue on this government. Mr Symond said that this package will see interest rates go up by possibly two to three per cent. Why, you might ask? Because this package favours the banks. It is no surprise to find the Liberal Party looking after their mates again.

talk.start.para: —You were looking after your mates with Brumby.
—This package favours the banks, and you know it, Senator Ferguson. You know it favours the banks.
—Order! Senator Conroy, would you please address the chair and make your language a little more temperate.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President.
—You look after John Brumby. That is all you have to do.
—Order! Senator Ferguson.

—The banks are favoured by this package. John Symond from Aussie Home Loans says that the red-hot competition which exists now, which he helped create, which brought bank interest rates down and which stopped the banks ripping off ordinary Australians, will not continue. He says it will be back to the bad old days under this package. That is right; back to the bad old days. There will be no competition for banks. He will lose 60 per cent of his profits. He says he will have no choice but to introduce higher interest rates or fees and charges on new accounts. That is John Symond, Aussie Home Loans.

speech.para: What did the Treasurer tell him when he told them about it? `It is an unintended consequence.' Where was the Treasurer admitting to this unintended consequence—that interest rates will go up—during the election? Evidence from builders last week said that the proposed package will see a massive increase in tax avoidance in their industry. Everybody knows that the building industry has been full of shonks and part of the black economy for years. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think it is in extremely poor taste for any senator to come into this chamber and accuse a professional person who has no capability of defending themselves in this place of being a stooge for some political party. He said that Mr Chris Murphy was a Liberal Party stooge. Those of us on this side might think that Professor Dixon is a Labor Party stooge, but none of us on this side of the chamber would say it. Professor Dixon has now been commissioned, as I understand it, by a Labor Party dominated committee to do some more work because they want to get some more evidence from this person who they think supplies them with information that suits their particular argument. It would be very easy for us to say that Professor Dixon is a Labor Party stooge. I am not saying that, but Senator Conroy did accuse a professional person of being a stooge. I think that is totally unwarranted. I think Senator Conroy would have satisfied the tone of this debate had he withdrawn that type of allegation against a professional who has no opportunity to defend himself in this chamber.

speech.para: What a mob of nitpickers. Of all the important things that are happening in Australia today, of all the important issues that they could raise in this chamber by way of questions that were asked of ministers today, questions that asked about a lot of serious matters, what does Senator Cook choose to take note of—bobs for jobs. What a thing to choose to take note of. Senator Cook must be running out of ideas. They got up and said that the government did not consult with scouts and guides prior to the introduction of the package. Most scouts and guides, in the old terminology that I know, are certainly well below voting age. The people they did consult with were their parents, their mums and dads. They are the people who make the decisions. They are the people who make the financial decisions in those families.

This reform package that the government has put together delivers to the mums and dads of scouts and guides the greatest benefits that this country has seen for a long time. It gives them some incentives to work more and to earn more because the personal income tax cuts that are available in this package put some incentive back into doing extra work and working overtime.

Someone raised the issue of authors, booksellers and printers. The other morning we had booksellers, printers and authors coming before a committee suggesting to us that they supported the tax package but that there should not be a tax on knowledge. All books, newspapers and magazines should be made GST free according to them. When questioned further, the printers and the authors were asked whether that meant they were quite happy for there to be a GST on clothing, housing and other essential items of life but that pornography and books of less repute should all be GST free. Their answer was yes. Have you ever heard of anybody pushing their own industry or their own particular barrow in such a way?

talk.start.para: —The mining industry do it all the time, and you listen to them.

—I do not think you are on the list, Senator Margetts, and I am not surprised. These people were pushing their own particular industry. Sure, we think there should be a tax on clothing, housing and even on food but we must make pornography GST free! They are the sorts of ridiculous arguments that we are now getting as this roadshow goes around Australia and all the likely suspects come before the Senate committee pushing their own particular barrow. `Yes, it is a good idea but we need something special just for us.'

speech.para: Senator Conroy says there will be no jobs created. Their preferred modeller, Professor Dixon, says that it is quite likely there will be 30,000 jobs created in the short term. Their modeller says 30,000 jobs.

talk.start.para: —Mr Chris Murphy from Econtech says 30,000 is a minimum. The only time you will get a 100,000 loss is if you model the most unrealistic scenario. The most unrealistic scenario says there will be a 100,000 loss, and that is the one that this unrealistic opposition chooses to use. Do not use the ones that have some credibility; use all of those modelling reports and modelling results which provide the most unrealistic figures. Senator Cook knows that because he has sat there and listened to the modellers give the evidence. You come into this chamber talking about `bobs for jobs'. Why don't you get back onto something serious? (Time expired)

—The issue that Senator Cook highlighted in commencing this debate—the issue for the scout association of the adverse impact of the GST on what is known as Jobs Week—is but one of many examples. Some are more serious than others, depending on your par ticular perspective. If you were involved in the scouting movement the issue of paying a GST on moneys raised in Jobs Week would be a very serious one. But it is just one example of the many issues that have been raised before the Senate committee on the GST. Senator Cook said earlier that the devil is in the detail and, as this committee has heard from many organisations about their concerns with the goods and services tax that the Liberal government is proposing, there are some very big devils in the detail of a goods and services tax.

speech.para: Senator Patterson, who prides herself on being a member of the scouting association—and a lifetime member, apparently, since the age of 10—said, `It is a pity that they did not come to us directly and have the matter clarified.' I do not know what Senator Patterson has been doing in terms of the scouting association, but that is exactly what the scouting association did. They wrote to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, seeking clarification about the impact of a goods and services tax on Jobs Week, and I will come to that issue in a moment. They got a letter back from Senator Kemp's office saying:
During "Jobs Week", Scouts appear to be acting on behalf of Scouts Australia as any payment goes to Scouts Australia. These activities are taxable—
that is, the GST is to be paid—
in the same manner as if they were provided by a private sector organisation.

So they did exactly what Senator Patterson urged them to do. They wrote to the office of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. And they received a letter signed not by Senator Kemp but by his taxation adviser, Ms Lesley East. You know a minister is in trouble when you see in the press that it was not Senator Kemp but his adviser who signed the letter. So the minister, Senator Kemp, blamed his adviser. He dashed around to the press and said, `I didn't sign the letter. My adviser signed the letter.'

What does Senator Kemp do in his office? Doesn't he read the correspondence that goes out in his name? There is no surer sign of a minister in trouble than one who blames his adviser for giving out what is correct advice in terms of the application of the GST on the activities of the scouting industry. There is another interesting aspect of this letter. In the second paragraph, it says:
Under the GST it is anticipated that the cost reductions to the sport, gambling and recreation services industry will be in the order of 3.9 per cent.

We are hearing a lot about cost reductions given out by the government to various industry sectors but, of course, cost reduction is not the final price effect. In fact, the impact on the sporting, gambling and recreational services industry will be a substantial increase in prices—not 10 per cent, but a substantial increase in prices; not a reduction of 3.9 per cent, as the government likes to falsely claim in this particular letter.

And what is the impact, for example, in the sport, gambling and recreational services industry? What do we have from Mr Murphy, who is I think Mr Howard's, the Prime Minister's, preferred modeller, his favourite modeller? My colleague Senator Conroy referred to him earlier as `a stooge of the government', and I think that is accurate. What do we have from Mr Murphy? We know that in this gambling and recreational services sector there will be some 8,000 jobs lost as a result of the price increase effect in the services sector.

I said earlier, of course, that this is not the only area where we have received substantial evidence. I urge senators to look at the effect on the Adelaide City Mission, a very important organisation providing a range of welfare and community services. It is going to lose hundreds of thousands of dollars as a consequence of the GST. The Blind Association in Western Australia will lose tens of thousands of dollars as a result of the GST. And, more importantly, they cannot provide replacement income to offset the income they, like the scouts association, are going to lose. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —It is with regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 27 January 1999 of former Senator George Howard Branson, a senator for the state of Western Australia from 1958 to 1971.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on Wednesday, 27 January 1999, of George Howard Branson, a senator for the State of Western Australia from 1958 to 1971, places on record its appreciation of his parliamentary service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

George Howard Branson was born on 23 February 1918 at Perth, Western Australia. George's father was a gold miner who pushed a barrow from Geraldton to Lawlers Creek. In 1924 the family moved to Babakin.

In 1940 George enlisted in the Australian Imperial Force and was appointed a lieutenant in August 1941. He served with the 2/4 Machine Gun Battalion in Malaya from 1942 until 1945. During this time George was captured and spent almost four years as a prisoner of war, when he worked on the now infamous Burma railway.

After the war, George returned to Babakin and farmed there for several years. In 1955 he moved his family to Perth. Then in 1958 George entered federal politics when he was elected to fill a casual vacancy. He was re-elected in 1964.

During his parliamentary career, George had wide service within committees, including the Privileges Committee, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Select Committee on Drug Trafficking and Drug Abuse. He was also Chairman of the Select Committee on Air Pollution from 1968. In addition to this, George was the Australian Political Adviser to the United Nations from September to December 1968. In his maiden speech in February 1959, George spoke optimistically about the future for Australia, which he described as being one of `unlimited potential', and particularly sang the praises of his home state. Through his parliamentary career he remained faithful to Western Australia and played a part in achievements such as the extension of television into the state's rural areas; Australia's northern beef roads program; and the Ord irrigation scheme. On his retirement from the Senate, colleagues commented that George had `brought into this place the patience and wisdom of the country man'.
On behalf of the government I extend to his wife Hannelore, his sons and their families, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I wish to associate the opposition with the condolence motion that has been moved on the death of former Senator George Howard Branson. We in the Labor Party also express our sincere regret at his recent passing.

speech.para: As the Manager of Government Business has indicated, former Senator Branson was a Western Australian by birth. He also clearly had a most distinguished career in the 2nd AIF. He was a prisoner of war for quite a considerable period—from 1942 to 1945—on the notorious Burma-Siam railway. He obviously suffered very great hardships during that period of time.

He served in the parliament from 1958, when he came in to fill a casual vacancy, through to his retirement in 1971—which, of course, represents two terms in the parliament. Like many others, he had very distinguished service on numerous parliamentary committees. He was the Chairman of the Select Committee on Air Pollution and, from all reports, was a dedicated member of parliament who very genuinely felt an obligation to the people of Western Australia and to his state. He demonstrated that commitment through great loyalty and hard work over a long period in this parliament.
Madam Deputy President, on behalf of the opposition I extend to former Senator Branson's family and friends our sincere condolences on his passing.
