talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate, recalling that 8 March 1999 is Commonwealth Day—
(1) reaffirms Australia's strong commitment to the work of the Commonwealth in bringing together a diverse group of countries across the world;
(2) notes that 1999 is a special year for the Commonwealth as it celebrates its fiftieth anniversary, marking the adoption of the London Declaration in 1949; and
(3) looks forward to the first Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting of the 21st century to be held in Canberra in 2001, the same year as Australia celebrates its Centenary of Federation.
I also table a copy of the Queen's Commonwealth Day message and I seek leave to incorporate the message in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The message read as follows—
From Her Majesty The Queen
Head of the Commonwealth

Music is the theme for Commonwealth Day this year. Throughout our fifty four countries, people will be celebrating and making music in as many ways as that, or more. Of course people of different generations and cultures tap their feet to quite different beats. But for all of us, young and old, music is an essential part of life for parties and entertainment; for ceremonies and celebrations.

For music knows no differences of language, no national boundaries. And because it has become such an important part of our cultural lives, it is a universal means of communicating with each other. The variety of music illustrates our diversity; its common tones and harmonies bring us together. Just like the Commonwealth.

In 1999 we celebrate the 50th anniversary of the modern Commonwealth. Fifty years ago, in 1949, India became the first republic with its own head of state to be a member of the Commonwealth. That paved the way to membership for many other countries, especially from Asia and Africa, all sharing links of history, a belief in democracy, and a will to work together. Today, the Commonwealth includes over a quarter of the world's population, spanning differences in race, creed and language, but sharing the same aspirations towards a better future.

This November, the leaders of the Commonwealth states will gather in South Africa for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I look forward to joining them there as they discuss the challenges of the new Millennium, as well as celebrating the Commonwealth's achievements in its life so far.

Let us then, in this anniversary year, look both backwards as well as forwards as we mark Commonwealth Day. While we continue to enjoy our favourite music, either by making it or listening to it, let us also celebrate the vigour and creativity that the next generation will bring to their music making. That is just one of the bonds that all the young people of the Commonwealth will share together on this special day.
Elizabeth R.
8 March 1999
Issued through The Chairman. The Joint Commonwealth Societies' Council.
c/o The Royal Commonwealth Society, 18 Northumberland Avenue, London WC2N 5BJ
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Report of Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the President, pursuant to standing order 38 I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998, together with submissions and Hansard recording of proceedings which were presented to a temporary chair of committees, Senator Knowles, on 25 February 1999. In accordance with the terms of the standing order, publication of the documents was authorised.
—Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to speak to—
—Can we dispose of the printing. Then you can move to take note of the report.
—I seek some guidance because I want to seek leave to make a statement with respect to the opposition's presentation of a minority report to this report.
—Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I sought leave, and I am grateful that it has been granted, to indicate to the Senate that with respect to the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the Regional Forest Agreements Bill that has just been referred to, the opposition will be seeking leave later this week to present the opposition minority report. The minority report was not contained within the report that was presented out of session last week. I want the Senate to be informed of that. The reason why I jumped up earlier was because I was concerned—obviously incorrectly—as to whether I needed to advise the Senate of the minority report before any motion to print the report was adopted. Having clarified all of that, I indicate to the Senate that we will be presenting our minority report later this week.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

The tabling of this report on the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 is a very important part in the progression towards one of the worst social and environmental outcomes through legislation that has come before this place certainly in the time I have been here, and in a long time. This committee was set up at the request of the Senate last year to look into the legislation by which the government intends to remove pretty well all environmental laws which would give it the ability to discharge its responsibility to look after the great wild forests of this country for the next 20 years. It also moves to give corporations which are logging those forests, in particular the big woodchip corporations, the ability to be compensated for any future federal move to protect the forests in the interests of the Australian public. So the corporations which have not paid a red cent for anything get compensated by the owners for acknowledging the owners' interests.

This is reprehensible legislation. I would have thought that with its ramifications on the Australian public's commercial interest, let alone its environmental interest, with the enormous amount of interest the Australian public has in its natural heritage and in particular its forest heritage, and with the phenomenal public alarm being demonstrated around the country, not least at the moment in Western Australia over the fate of the forests, there would have been a Senate inquiry open and available to the competing interests right around the country.

As I said at the time, and have said in my report, this inquiry was effectively a sham if it was meant to produce a popularly available forum from which a diligent evaluation of popular feeling in this country could be made and the information made available. The Labor Party has not yet presented its report, but the government members on the committee, of course, have submitted a majority report which effectively rubber stamps what the government's legislation stands for.

I ask everybody interested in this matter to look at that report. What you will see is a ringing support of the interests of the woodchip corporations. But what more could be expected when this committee met only once at the outset in Melbourne—Melbourne being in the one state on the mainland which does not have an export woodchip mill, although valuable forests from Victoria are now being exported through the wholly owned Japanese woodchip mill, Harris Daishowa, in Eden—and had a supplementary hearing here in Canberra one night?

Although the advertising of this committee's deliberations occurred in the week before Christmas and members of the Australian public were given only a month in which to make submissions, nearly 400 submissions came to this committee. That is surely something out of the box! But the way in which the hearings were held effectively excommunicated most of those people who had gone to the trouble in the Christmas holidays to make those submissions, and one only has to look at the submissions to see how much people cared.

If you were from Tasmania, you had to cross Bass Strait to get to the hearings. If you lived anywhere but in Victoria, you had to travel an enormous distance. If you were in Western Australia, you had to cross the Nullarbor. But even then, the odds were totally stacked against the public making live representations to this committee. A handful of people were able to present their case. Of course, they presented a compelling case on economic, environmental and employment grounds for the government not to be able to get away with this legislation, which cuts away the Commonwealth's responsibility for forests and effectively hands it to the woodchip corporations. The logging interests, of course, certainly had to have their balanced say to the committee.

I must say that I feel a great deal of thanks should go from this chamber to the staff who were working on this committee, because they had to do a Houdini act to try to appear to balance the presentation, at the behest of the committee, in a situation which was totally imbalanced. If you look at those submissions, you will see that the representations from the public saying `Do not pass this legislation' far outweigh the sectional interests of the big logging corporations. You would not know it from the time and space allocated in this report—the majority report—to this chamber.

The majority report to this chamber does not deliver a fair reflection of how the public out there feels and what the committee was given in evidence. If this is an example of how the committee system works, I think there is something seriously wrong with it. Obviously, the `something' is the govern ment's ability to use a committee like this to get the outcome it wants through the dint of numbers—not through the dint of reasoning, not through the dint of evidence coming from the public, but through the sheer dint of numbers to deliver an outcome wanted by the woodchip corporations.

Why would they do that? As the evidence to the committee made it clear, the woodchip corporations are very big contributors to both the major political parties in this place—over half a million dollars in the last year for which we have the figures—and I can only come to the conclusion that that money counts extraordinarily well as far as influence is concerned in outcomes. Otherwise, how can you have it that opinion polls around this country show 70 per cent—or, in Western Australia, over 80 per cent—of people are opposed to the continuing destruction of the great wild forests of this nation and the wildlife in them—

talk.start.para: —How much does Dick Smith give you?

—That is an unparliamentary comment, but it is the sort of loutish comment I would expect from the Labor Party on this matter. The fact is that the corporations are having their way against a huge preponderance of public feeling.

speech.para: The government believes that, after this legislation gets through—if it passes this chamber, and one has to accept that it probably will, with Labor supporting the government—there will thenceforth be so-called peace in the forests. One thing that became abundantly clear in these hearings—and you will not see this reflected in the majority report—is that there will be nothing of the sort. Every community group, every indigenous group and every environmental group which appeared before the committee, opposed to the woodchippers digging deeper and chainsawing deeper into our forests, made it abundantly clear that they will not give up on their fight to have the right thing done—the forests protected—and, moreover, the industry translocated across to the plantation option which is there and available now.

Instead of that win-win situation, we have the cloud of big corporations working through the political establishment of the old parties, and the end result of that is this majority report which does not reflect community thinking. In that sense, this committee has been a total failure in representing the interests of the Australian people.

talk.start.para: —I will not speak long on this Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee report and not in great depth on the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 because we will have the opportunity to address that when the legislation comes before the Senate. Suffice it to say the Democrats, my colleague Senator Woodley and I have a dissenting report. The Democrats do not believe that this legislation should be passed as it stands.

speech.para: Whilst it was a very unsatisfactorily brief and truncated inquiry, it was quite sufficient to at least highlight the number of problems that are present with the RFA process around the country and the real con we will be putting over ourselves if we actually think this is going to solve the so-called forest problem. Clearly, if this legislation did go through, it would entrench many of the concerns that have been expressed over many years and indeed are growing in terms of both the extent of them and the number of people in the community who also share those concerns.

It does not resolve one of the longest running and contentious issues to face this nation. It fails to deliver on jobs. It unfairly discriminates against the plantation industry. It will destroy more areas of native forest, including old-growth areas. It does not protect biodiversity. It discriminates unfairly against other important cultural values. It will mostly be controlled by state governments which have vested or financial short-term interests in the outcomes. It removes the Commonwealth's legitimate oversight of Australia's biodiversity in our world heritage obligations, among other things.

I would like to speak briefly of the concerns about the processes of this inquiry, which have been alluded to by Senator Brown and Senator Forshaw in his brief comment before, in terms of the unnecessary speed of the inquiry and the somewhat unusual process of the committee reporting out of session last week. I would like to also repeat the commendation of the committee secretariat because I think the pressure that was put on them to try to deal with the huge number of submissions, the great deal of public interest and the extremely short time frame was very unreasonable. I am concerned that it potentially places committee staff in a situation where they can unfairly be portrayed as not being competent or capable when clearly they were put in a situation that was virtually untenable.

I am also concerned about the reputation of the Senate and Senate committees as a whole when we have processes such as this which clearly generate an enormous amount of public interest and make people from whatever side of the argument feel that they are not being taken seriously, that it is a sham inquiry just for the sake of appearances and that legitimate concerns of the public are not taken on board. I think, unfortunately, that is the situation that did occur with this inquiry. It ends up reflecting very badly on the Senate itself, on the parliament and on the Senate committee process when clearly inadequate time frames are allowed to consider issues of great importance, great significance and great public interest. I would like to register the Democrats' concern and dissatisfaction about that.

The need for Senator Forshaw to make his statement before indicates the problems that have occurred in terms of the correct printing of this report. I assume our dissenting report is appropriately incorporated in the report that has been tabled, although I know there were some problems last week with that. Again I think that highlights the inadequate time frame that was allowed for this. I have no idea why the report needed to be tabled out of session last week and supposedly in some urgency when, when we get here this week, the bill is not listed for debate. Apparently we were meant to do all this irregular process and put enormous pressure on Senate committees that are already under-resourced and overstretched so that we could meet the apparently absolutely urgent imperative of the government to bring on this legislation today. It is not only not on today but, at least as far as we know, it is not listed at all for this week. Regardless of one's views about the content of this legislation—whether you feel it is good or bad—that process makes it very difficult for us as parliamentarians, makes it impossible for the Senate committee staff, Senate staff, and generally brings the parliament into disrepute.

It is probably also worth noting the action, prior to this debate coming on, of the withdrawal of a notice of motion of Senator Murphy's which was aimed at referring these broader matters relating to regional forest agreements to a Senate references committee in recognition of the range and importance of the issues that relate to forestry, particularly the regional forest agreements and, again, the depth and strength of public concern. If that motion had been continued and voted on and the issues were put to a Senate committee, it would have at least enabled these issues to be examined in the depth that they deserve, but, unfortunately, that motion was withdrawn by the Labor Party just a few minutes ago as well. So clearly we are not going to have that opportunity.

We have not had an adequate opportunity with this legislation to address those issues. Unfortunately, that looks like all the examination we are going to get of what is clearly a crucial issue. In the Democrats' view it clearly puts the future of our forests, indeed the future of our forestry industries and people dependent on the timber industries, very much at risk. To lock up some public resources for the long-term benefit of foreign owned woodchip companies is an outcome, from the Democrats' perspective, we find hard to believe and something that should be adequately examined.

Unfortunately, because of the time frame imposed on the committee—and, again, this is no reflection on the committee staff or the members of the committee from all parties who had to work within the time frame that the Senate imposed on them—I think this is a perfect example of an inadequate process which reflects badly on the Senate and on the parliament. I hope senators keep that in mind next time there is consideration given to appropriate reporting dates for contentious legislation.

talk.start.para: —I had not intended to speak in this debate on the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee report because my colleague Senator Brown has been following this committee and working very hard to put the community's view and give the community a chance to give their view in this regard. I just wanted to make a comment on one of these issues of process. Here we have a situation where the committee, with the votes of the Labor Party opposition and the government, agreed to table this report out of session. For all the arguments we have heard, we have realised that the government basically have not lived up to any commitments that they made or may have made on this issue.

speech.para: What concerns me, however, is that, given the agreement by the Labor opposition, the Labor opposition's response is not here. It was an out of session tabling, and we have the actual report being tabled in the Senate today. I would be concerned that what we are seeing here is the desire of the Labor opposition not to be seen to be part of this process, part of the debate, to try to take the heat away from their own position on this issue because we do not know what their position is.

This whole process is of great concern to me. Firstly, they agreed to the out of session tabling but, secondly, when we get here several days later, the smaller political parties with fewer resources are able to present their response on time and the Labor opposition is saying `some time later this week'. That is not good enough. Perhaps I could seek leave to continue my remarks, and maybe this document will still be on the table. Then we can look at both these reports together at some stage in the future when they are available.

talk.start.para: —You can only seek leave to continue your remarks provided nobody else wants to speak, Senator Margetts. I understand Senator Forshaw is seeking the call.

—Firstly, I was going to make some comments at greater length when the time came later this week, provided leave will be granted, with respect to the opposition's position on this legislation, the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 . I will no doubt still have that opportunity. Secondly, we will deal with the legislation when it comes on, and that will provide a further opportunity to consider all of the reports of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee—the majority report, the dissenting reports from the Greens and the Democrats and the opposition minority report. But I do need to correct a couple of things that have just been stated by Senator Margetts and Senator Bartlett.

speech.para: Absolutely no inference can be drawn from the fact that the opposition has not presented its report today along with the majority report that somehow we are trying to dodge this debate. In fact, nothing could be further from the truth. I can assure the honourable senators from the Democrats and the Greens that we have almost finished our report. In fact, a large part of the draft has been prepared and is with the secretariat, and I am in the process of finalising that.
Senator Brown interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will ignore that, the start of what I think was going to be a rather snide insinuation.
—Please do, Senator.

—The reason we have taken a little bit longer than the majority report and, indeed, the dissenting reports is that we are looking at the specific options and propositions that would be available to the Senate to deal with this legislation properly. The majority report has come down after quite a detailed analysis of evidence. It is quite a lengthy document—and we received the full copy, I think, just a day or two before it was presented to the President—but all the majority report from the government says is `pass the legislation unamended'.

speech.para: Basically, the position of the Democrats and the Greens is that they do not agree with this legislation at all, they do not agree with the RFA process, throw it all out. That is their position. Rather, the Labor Party's position, as has already been flagged in the debate in the lower house by the shadow minister, is that we are looking at some specific proposed amendments which we believe will go to the heart of the issues raised by many of the witnesses during the proceedings concerning the RFA process.
Senator Brown interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You can sit there and make your snide interjections, but why don't you just wait a couple of days?
—We know it's coming. It'll be more of the same cop-out.
—Order! Senator Brown! Senator Forshaw has the call.
—Senator Brown, you know nothing.
—Wait and see.

—Yes, you wait and see. Mr Acting Deputy President, we are giving very detailed consideration to the sorts of amendments that we believe this Senate should look at when the debate comes on, and we flagged that as well in the debate in the other place.

speech.para: It has been put to us that the opposition should not have agreed to the tabling out of session. It is important to understand the process that occurred here. This bill was referred to this committee late last year. At the time the issue came on in the Senate, we argued that there should be a later reporting date than was first proposed, namely 15 February. The reason was that we wanted more time to allow for more public hearings and to allow the committee to have the opportunity of possibly going to other states and, given that the intervening period would encompass Christmas, New Year, the school holidays and so forth, we thought this legislation deserved more time. We argued that position here in the chamber, but we lost.

The government said at the time that this was urgent legislation and had to be dealt with at the start of the session this year. When the committee's hearings got under way and key constitutional issues were raised regarding the legislation, there was a need to get a response from the department and from the Attorney-General's office. The government then acknowledged that maybe the committee did need a bit more time, so there was a further extension.

At that time, the government put forward that it wanted the report to be tabled out of session—from memory, the date was 25 February. It wanted it to be tabled on that day so that the parliament would be in a position to deal with the legislation on the first day of the sitting week—today. It was put to us that it needed that extra time between the 23rd and today to consider the report.

Opposition senators of the committee—and I do not wish to go into confidential or private discussions—maintained our position that we thought more time was still required. But understanding the numbers on the committee and understanding the numbers in the Senate, we were not going to win that argument. That is the position. We wanted the opportunity for that extra time to consider in even greater depth than we had been allowed all the submissions and information that had been raised. I imagine we will be presenting our minority report within the next couple of days, certainly this week. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
