The speeches read as follows—
WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1998

The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1998 will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to remove the regulation of superannuation as an allowable matter in federal awards. The bill will mean that businesses and employees would no longer be forced to have their superannuation rights and obligations governed by duplicate layers of regulation—the existing layer of regulation created by the award system will be subsumed by rights and obligations under the Superannuation Guarantee legislation. This measure will reduce compliance costs, minimise complexity and simplify administration.
It will also enhance the process of award simplification.

This proposal is not new. When the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 was originally introduced, the allowable award matters proposed did not include superannuation. The amendments subsequently agreed with the Australian Democrats retained superannuation in the list of allowable award matters as a temporary measure, on the in-principle basis that superannuation could be removed from award regulation in conjunction with the implementation of the Coalition's `choice of funds' legislative package.

The continued pursuit of this sensible measure to remove the regulation of superannuation from the award system was specifically reaffirmed in the Coalition's workplace relations policy More Jobs Better Pay released during the recent 1998 federal election campaign.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission, in its 1994 superannuation test case decision, recognised that the Superannuation Guarantee legislation established the safety net for superannuation entitlements. Removing superannuation from award regulation reflects the safety net role of the Superannuation Guarantee legislation. Those employers and employees who wish to use the workplace relations system to regulate occupational superannuation beyond the safety net level can continue to do so through the agreement making processes of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 or through over-award payments.

An earlier bill dealing with this matter, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1997, was introduced in the House of Representatives on 4 December 1997, along with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997, which contained provisions for the choice of superannuation funds. That bill was passed by the House, but did not pass through the Senate in the previous term of the Coalition Government. The bill introduced today is similar to the previous bill, but now includes transitional provisions that were not previously necessary (as the removal of superannuation from awards would have then been effected as part of the award simplification process introduced by the 1996 amendments).

The present bill will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to prevent the Commission from dealing with disputes about superannuation by arbitration. Superannuation will cease to be an allowable award matter, and the Commission will not be able to make exceptional matters orders about superannuation.

The transitional provisions in the bill will have the effect that existing superannuation provisions in awards will cease to operate after a six-month transitional period, and the Commission will then be required to remove superannuation provisions from awards. The bill will preserve existing superannuation clauses beyond this six-month period, where they are `special consent provisions'. This is consistent with the treatment of special consent provisions by the award simplification process under the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996. Special consent provisions are provisions of awards made in accordance with particular Wage Fixing Principles of the Commission that were put in place through National Wage Decisions from 1991 to 1995. Such special consent provisions are no longer provided for and therefore this preservation will not be an avenue to introduce new or amended superannuation provisions into the award system.

Schedule 2 of the bill amends the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 so as to enable employers to continue to use `notional earnings bases', based on current award provisions, in determining obligations under that act, even after the award provisions cease to operate. This will ensure that employers do not incur additional superannuation costs as a result of the removal of superannuation from awards. In combination with the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 1998, the changes in this bill will mean that `flat dollar amounts' will also continue to be recognised for superannuation guarantee purposes. These amendments will complement the new choice of funds arrangements contained in the Choice of Funds Bill, introduced into the Senate on 17 February 1999. In combination, these bills deliver genuine superannuation reform.
This bill will have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
MOTOR VEHICLE STANDARDS AMENDMENT BILL 1998

The Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 1998 amends the legislative framework for the setting of standards for motor vehicles when first supplied for use in transport in Australia and provides for improvements to the administration of the act.

The proposed amendments will provide a wider definition of a "vehicle standard" to include standards designed to promote energy saving. This will allow the development of a standard for model specific fuel consumption labelling as announced by the Prime Minister on 20 November 1997 in his statement on greenhouse issues "Safeguarding the Future: Australia's Response to Climate Change". This amendment is an important early step in implementing Australia's international commitments to reducing the level of growth in emissions of greenhouse gases to 8 per cent above 1990 levels by 2010.

This standard is being developed by the Australian Greenhouse Office and will be subject to the normal consultative and development processes. The standard will provide consumers with comparative information about the fuel consumption of particular models of motor vehicle so they will be able to take this information into account when purchasing a vehicle. In the longer term, it is hoped that this initiative will encourage industry to develop more fuel efficient vehicles.

The bill also includes amendments to establish the position of "Associate Administrator". The Administrator performs the function of my delegate and can exercise certain of the powers under the legislation. The appointment of one or more Associate Administrators allows more routine matters to be dealt with at a more appropriate level.

The remaining amendments improve the administration of the act by correcting errors and restoring the connection between this act and the Customs Act 1901. They are mechanical in nature but designed to improve the enforcement provisions of the legislation. Importantly, one amendment removes a duplication of penalties by removing criminal sanctions where there are already administrative sanctions.
The net budgetary impact of the amendments will be nil.
The amendments will come into force on the day on which they receive Royal Assent.
AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1998
Purpose of the Bill
This bill amends the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990.

The Australian sporting community has been fully consulted on these amendments, from the administrators of our peak national sports bodies to the elite athletes who are themselves subject to drug testing. They recognise that the Agency must have the flexibility to keep abreast of change.
The proposed amendments will ensure that Australia's anti-doping regime is more efficient, fairer to athletes who are themselves subject to drug testing, but, importantly, tougher on drug cheats.
Background
In 1990, Australia became the first country in the world to establish a national sports drug testing authority under legislation.

However, the act, in its current form, has hampered ASDA's pursuit of best practice principles. In late 1997, the Government initiated an independent review of the ASDA legislation. That review recommended the removal of significant levels of operational detail from the act. The Government endorsed those recommendations.
Major Features of the Bill

The amendments streamline the ASDA Act so that it clearly establishes the legislative framework under which ASDA will operate. The act will no longer contain detailed operating instructions. These will be removed to subordinate legislation.
Through the Regulations, ASDA will be required to conduct testing in accordance with a "charter of athlete rights" that preserves all rights which this Parliament guaranteed for athletes in 1990.

The bill strengthens the capacity of ASDA to deal with positive test results recorded by foreign athletes. If an international body takes no action, ASDA will be able to notify a relevant Australian sports body so that it may take appropriate action. This creates a level playing field for Australian athletes in Australia.

The bill puts in place a mechanism to enable the Australian Customs Service to pass information to ASDA about prohibited imports which are also banned for use in sport. The Agency will use this information to better plan its testing activities.

The bill provides for the establishment of an Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee. The Committee will provide scientific and medical expertise to support ASDA's drug testing activities, and the anti-doping policies of national sporting organisations. The establishment of this Committee is strongly supported by the Australian sporting community.

The Committee will assist laboratories determine whether the presence of a banned endogenous substance is due to the substance being present at naturally high levels for that competitor, or due to doping—in other words, cheating.

Secondly, the Committee will provide independent approval of athlete requests to use prohibited substances for therapeutic reasons where the athlete has a serious medical condition. The Committee will only do this where the rules of the sporting organisation permit therapeutic usage.
Finally, the Committee will be able to provide expert medical advice to the sports doping tribunals that hear cases of alleged doping offences.

The bill also provides a legislative framework for State and Territory governments to enact complementary legislation that will enable ASDA to undertake drug testing on State level competitors. This measure has the strong support of all State and Territory Ministers for Sport.

In addition, the bill will enable ASDA to provide `safety checking services' for sporting organisations to test for the presence of substances such as alcohol, which can impair judgement and compromise the safety of competitors.
Financial Impact Statement

The Agency's 1998-99 budget will absorb the costs of the establishment and operation of the Medical Advisory Committee. Annual funding required by the Committee in future years will be taken up in the 1999-2000 budget.

I am sure that most Australians will want to ensure that the Australian sporting ethos based on honesty, fair play, excellence, and opportunity for all, is preserved for future generations of Australian sports people. This bill will enable ASDA to adopt world's best practice when delivering drug testing services. It will provide the Australian sporting community with an independent, high quality and accessible anti-doping program, and so enable Australian sport to deter drug use by athletes.

I must also take this opportunity to stress that this bill is only one expression of the Government's commitment to drug free sport. The Government is currently working on pulling together a whole suite of anti-doping measures with a view to developing a comprehensive and coordinated anti-doping strategy.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1998
This bill amends a number of acts within the Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry portfolio.

The government announced on 11 December 1996 that Article 39(3) of the WTO Agreement on Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights required Australia to provide protection for undisclosed test data submitted in respect of the evaluation of a new active constituent for an agricultural or veterinary chemical product. The proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 will provide five years protection for such data and thus remove any doubt as to whether or not Australia is fulfilling its obligations under Article 39(3).

The proposed amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 will correct the unforeseen impacts of the operation of the Government's Domestic Market Support scheme during the recent Victorian gas crisis. During the crisis, many milk manufacturing plants in Victoria incurred significant financial losses due to lost production, factory conversion outlays and higher operating costs. In addition, the operation of the Domestic Market Support scheme during this period imposed further hardship on farmers and manufacturers, and created inequities within the Victorian dairy industry.

The proposed amendments will remedy this problem by providing for two special payments. The first payment is a rebate to those manufacturers who, under the Domestic Market Support scheme, were required to pay a levy on milk disposed of at the factory during the gas crisis. This rebate is designed to offset financial losses incurred by manufacturers through the imposition of levy in this situation.

The second payment is a payment to the producers of milk which was disposed of on-farm during the gas crisis. Under the Domestic Market Support scheme, milk has to be delivered to a manufacturer before a farmer becomes eligible for a Domestic Market Support payment. This payment will allow producers, upon application, to receive the same entitlement as if their milk had been delivered to a factory. This payment does not extend to market milk.

The payments will be financed from the Australian Dairy Corporation's Domestic Fund. This Fund finances the Domestic Market Support scheme, using monies collected from dairy industry levies on manufacturing and market milk. Accordingly, there is no financial obligation upon the Commonwealth.

I would note that these amendments constitute the government's response to concerns raised by the Australian Dairy Industry Council, and clearly illustrates the government's preparedness to facilitate a lessening of the impact of the Victorian gas crisis on the Australian dairy industry.
The bill amends the Export Control Act 1982 to ensure that Australia's export control legislation provides appropriate coverage for contemporary administrative arrangements.

Under current export inspection arrangements there is a strong move for exporters to assume more responsibility for the quality of their product under quality systems approved and supervised by AQIS. The amendments to the Export Control Act 1982 seek to facilitate this move by allowing for the appropriate coverage of these systems in delegated legislation, and by strengthening the enforcement powers in the act in line with Commonwealth law administration policy.

The purpose of the amendment to the Imported Food Control act 1992 is to clarify some aspects of the act which have previously been confusing and to enable consistent application of the act across areas which have previously been left open. This is sought as a result of inconsistencies being found by officers working with the act.
As a result of the amendment, AQIS anticipates a more effective and efficient service to industry as it clarifies areas of the act that have previously been in doubt.

All food imported into Australia must firstly comply with the requirements of the Quarantine Act 1908 before being inspected against the requirements of the Imported Food Control Act 1992. Accordingly the proposed amendments to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 will have no effect on Australia's quarantine standards.
The purpose of the proposed amendment to the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994 is to make naming of new varieties easier.
Currently, an anomalous restriction exists which precludes any duplication of plant variety names regardless of whether varieties are protected or currently in commerce.
The need not to repeat a name makes the checking of proposed names to ensure novelty, an unnecessarily laborious process for both the applicant and the PBR office.

Therefore it is proposed to allow limited duplication of variety names provided varieties with the same name are from an entirely different "plant class" and are unlikely to be confused in the market place. Duplication of names in closely related cereal crops such as wheat, barley and oats would not be accepted.
A list of plant classes, maintained by the PBR office, will be accessible to prospective PBR applicants free of charge.
This proposed amendment is in conformity with the international standards on the matter and will promote the use of a single name for each variety, regardless of the country in which it is marketed.
Debate (on motion by Senator Quirke) adjourned.
Ordered that these bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

debateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ian Macdonald) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 delivers on the Government's commitment to address legitimate community concern regarding possible exploitation of consumers and excessive profit taking by business in the transition to the new tax system.

The bill inserts a new Part VB into the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA) to give the ACCC special transitional powers to monitor prices for 3 years from 1 July 1999. The monitoring will identify instances where consumers have not fully benefited from reductions in tax rates, or would otherwise be exposed to greater than necessary price rises.

The bill prohibits price exploitation during the 3 year transitional period. Price exploitation occurs if the price for the supply of a good or service is unreasonably high, having regard to the tax changes under the new system. It is recognised that many factors may affect price and, therefore, price exploitation will not occur if the unreasonably high price is attributable to the supplier's costs, supply and demand conditions, or any other relevant matter. The ACCC will issue guidelines relating to price exploitation, in particular, about when prices will be regarded as unreasonably high.

Prosecutions for breaches of the prohibition on price exploitation will be taken by the ACCC in the Federal Court, with penalties of up to $10 million for a body corporate, and up to $500,000 for a person other than a body corporate.

The ACCC will have extensive information gathering powers to facilitate its price monitoring and prosecution roles. It will also be able to seek injunctions to restrain breaches of the prohibition. As an alternative to taking court action, the ACCC will have power to accept voluntary undertakings relating to prices and price setting, using its existing powers under the TPA to accept undertakings.

The ACCC will also have power to issue a notice to a corporation that it considers has contravened the prohibition against price exploitation. These notices will constitute prima facie evidence, in proceedings by the ACCC to seek penalties or to obtain an injunction, that the price charged is unreasonably high, and is not attributable to supplier's costs, supply and demand conditions, or any other relevant matter. It will be for the corporation to whom the notice is issued to provide evidence to the contrary.

The ACCC will also be able to issue a second type of notice to a corporation, relating to supplies that may be made in the future. In this notice the ACCC will specify a maximum price which, in its opinion, may be charged for a supply referred to in the notice. That is, the ACCC will be able to provide a warning to a corporation that if it supplies above the maximum price specified, that price will, in the ACCC's opinion, constitute price exploitation. This notice will not constitute prima facie evidence in future proceedings, but the ACCC will be able to publish details of the notice as it sees fit, including in national newspapers. Adverse publicity should help to discourage price exploitation and in addition provide consumers with information of assistance in avoiding unnecessary price rises.

Limitations on the Commonwealth's constitutional power mean that these measures cannot extend across the whole economy without the cooperation of the States and Territories. To facilitate that cooperation, the bill creates a form of text to be known as the New Tax System Price Exploitation Code. This Code replicates the provisions of the new Part VB in the Schedule to the TPA, and also contains the other provisions and regulations of the TPA so far as they relate to Part VB, modified to refer to "persons" rather than "corporations". The application of this Code by State and Territory legislation will provide economy-wide coverage of these anti-profiteering measures.

Competitive pressures that already exist in the economy should largely ensure that the benefits of reductions in tax rates are passed on to consumers in the form of lower prices. Nevertheless, this bill is necessary to deal with those instances where price exploitation could occur. The substantial penalties that can be imposed, demonstrate the Government's determination to ensure that consumers receive the full benefits of the changes to the tax system.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till 19 April 1999, in accordance with the order agreed to on 25 November 1998.
Ordered that A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 and the package of bills relating to the new tax system be taken together for their remaining stages.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Civil Aviation Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 234 and made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988 , be disallowed.

The proposed amendments to the Civil Aviation Regulations represent, in our view, the next step in the Howard government's plans to privatise air traffic control services and firefighting services at certain airports. Already we have seen the launch of the firefighters campaign to resist this government's plans to privatise their service. Firefighters have grave concerns about the impact that the plan will have on their future and on the future of airport safety in general.

The same concerns, the same issues, arise from the government's plans to privatise air traffic control services. Of course, no-one knows exactly the current state of those plans or how far they have been developed—not the air traffic controllers whose jobs and futures may be at stake, not the aviation industry, not the travelling public and certainly not this parliament.

Air safety and the aviation bureaucracy have been very topical of late. We have seen the chairman of CASA launching a damning public attack on the highly regarded BASI. At the Senate estimates committee hearings we heard of `letters in the bottom of the drawer', threats to careers, `cronyism and capture', influence by major airlines, lawyers taking action to get hold of important documents, et cetera. It was quite an extraordinary day. These are issues that the government would obviously prefer that the opposition did not raise. I think they would prefer the `let's not talk about it and it might go away' approach. It certainly is not going to go away in relation to this matter.

Despite what we have seen and heard, much about aviation policy and direction remains unclear. In the opposition's view we need transparency, we need a clear message and we need to have the government clearly articulate where it wants to go. I suspect, however, that the government has no clear idea that its own traffic control system and navigation is on the blink and that its own destination is unknown.

What we do know is this: we know that Airservices has been reviewed, but we do not know the results of the review or the results of the review of the administration of air safety. We know that last year the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, John Anderson, confirmed that the government had agreed to `consider introducing competition into some aspects of Airservices Australia's tower business'. He went on to say:
The action we have taken accords with a number of firm expressions of interest that the government has received from new airport lessees seeking to make tower services contestable.
We know that he has told us not to worry about it when the issue was discussed in the other place. We know that in December last year Airservices Australia announced:
In line with Government policy on competition for air traffic services, an immediate start will be made with a process to test the market for alternative Air Traffic Control service providers.

We also know CASA has been asked to develop standards to use in the provision of air traffic control services. We know that there have been discussions between Airservices and potential providers of air traffic control services. And we also know that Minister Anderson gave in the other place what amounted to an unpaid advertisement for a possible provider, Serco—an organisation, in our view, with a questionable industrial relations record if ever there was one.

We get glimpses of what is going on, but we do not get to see the full picture. The one full picture we have seen is of widespread industry concern about the government's plans. We know pilots, air traffic controllers, airport operators, the airlines, small general aviation businesses and a plethora of others within the aviation industry believe that they are not being properly consulted about the government's plans for Australian aviation. We still have not been told what the introduction of `competition into some aspects of tower business' means in reality, or what `making tower services contestable' actually involves in terms of the specific detail. We have not been told which of the lessees want their tower services privatised.

What is more, we have no guarantees yet on the price or standard of the privatised services. We have absolutely no guarantee that new private operators will not cut corners or compromise safety. We have no guarantee that the public's capacity—through the government and the parliament—to control, direct and scrutinise these services will be maintained. We have no guarantee that, given possible increased insurance costs and the costs of regulating any private providers, overall costs to Airservices would not increase.

Privatisation or `alternative sources of supply' or `introducing competition' or `making services contestable' or `local ownership'—or whatever euphemism this government may be able to come up with—has generally led to the following wherever it has been implemented: job losses, higher costs, lower levels of service and compromised standards. In the United States, the Federal Aviation Administration has been ordered by the judicial system to cancel its program of privatising some of the towers and to reconsider its whole contracting out pro cess. Why we don't take the lessons from overseas, I do not know.

We cannot allow the profit motive to obscure a clear focus on safety. We must have transparency; we must have openness; we must make sure that the issue can be publicly scrutinised. The Airservices operation is already an extremely lean outfit. The only way to make a profit in a number of towers would be to increase costs to the industry and therefore the public, or to reduce costs to business and therefore cut services. Promises by Minister Anderson that somebody else can do it cheaper are simply hollow. A cheaper service is often, and in this case almost certainly would be, a poorer service. That is a risk that I think recent events in Australian politics have shown that we cannot afford. We certainly cannot afford the risk in the critical area of air traffic control.

What controls are proposed on costs? What will happen at the busy general aviation airports that are significant training institutions? Who will provide the services there? We cannot afford to let the issue of safety in the air be buried in company boardrooms. Who will be responsible if an accident occurs under a privatised air traffic control system: the private operator, the airport lessee, the government or nobody? Whose responsibility will it be ultimately? Would it be, as we have seen in many areas of this government's operations, a commercial-in-confidence matter and therefore devoid of parliamentary scrutiny as well? In such a critical issue as aviation safety, this is simply not good enough.

In short, on this issue we believe that we are being kept in the dark, that we are being patted on the head and told not to worry about it and told that `safety will not be compromised'. Labor does not believe that that is an acceptable way to go about making decisions and devising policies in these utterly crucial areas. There are too many questions arising from this for the Australian public to sit relaxed and comfortable in their seats.

Making fundamental change to the law of the land by regulation without prior parliamentary debate seems to be this government's new approach to parliament. It seems that, in question time in the other place, the time is used to boost the sales of recent publications by opposition members, while the government make their fundamental changes by regulation rather than by legislation.

These amendments redefine air traffic service as including Airservices Australia, the current provider of air traffic control services, or a person providing air traffic services in cooperation with Airservices Australia or under an arrangement with Airservices Australia. This redefinition enables the government to sell the responsibility to provide air traffic control and the air traffic control towers and potentially other air traffic control services by recognising providers other than Airservices Australia. That is axiomatic and that is the crux of the matter. No fancy footwork or attempts to disguise the plans by saying that Airservices Australia will still be responsible for the standard of the service will suffice. That will not suffice. This is about privatisation, in our view. We have absolutely no doubt that that is ultimately what this will lead to.

In this case, the parliament is being asked to sign off on a measure that potentially shifts responsibility for providing these services away from Airservices Australia with absolutely no detail backing it up. In effect, we are being asked to sign off on the privatisation of air traffic control without the faintest clue about what that will mean in reality. We are simply not prepared to give the government this kind of licence. Irrespective of their ultimate views on the question of privatisation of these services, I do not believe that the Democrats, the Greens or Senator Harradine should let the government get away with such an extraordinary snub to parliamentary and public accountability.

What we should be saying to the government is: if you want to privatise these services, come back into this place and put your specific plans on the table. You tell us exactly what you are planning to do, what the government's timetable is, what the standards will be, what guarantees there are that prices for services by private providers will be regulated, what the impact on aviation costs will be and how the government is ultimately going to go about it. The government should come in here openly and in an air of transparency and tell the chamber how many jobs it thinks will be lost, what guarantees there are about the integrity of potential providers, how the government is going to guarantee safety and how the government is going to make sure small regional airports are not adversely affected.

The government should come in here and explain and justify its plans to the Australian public. It should come in here and justify its plans. Until the government does this and until the government provides these concrete assurances on safety for travellers in the community, the government is not entitled to ask us, the Senate, on behalf of our constituents, to blithely sign off on these amendments. But I do not think, and I doubt very much, that the government is in fact going to take up what I believe is a fairly generous offer on behalf of the Labor Party. Why is that? Because the government knows that the majority of Australians are going to say, as the opposition is saying, that air traffic control should remain a public operation motivated by the need to protect safety, not the need to make a profit.

In opposing these amendments, the opposition is saying very firmly and very clearly that air safety is not an issue of service provision; it is primarily an issue of government responsibility. I urge all senators to put the brakes on this headlong rush to destination unknown and support the opposition in rejecting amendments that effectively give the government the go-ahead to privatise vital air traffic control services without divulging details of their plan, without doing the work on what that would mean and without having the courage to engage in a full public debate about this issue.

talk.start.para: —I commend Senator Mackay on her speech. She has convinced me. The Democrats are very happy to support this disallowance motion, but I would like to give a couple of comments as well for the minister to cogitate over. Perhaps he will also support the disallowance motion when he understands the nature of the problem.

speech.para: It would be good for the minister to know that I have in my office a stack of submissions and letters from people. I suppose I should not exaggerate. I am not sure just how high the stack would be, but they come from every industry group associated with aviation—that is, from many private operators, from individual people and from some who, I must say, will not even give me their names, and one really cannot take seriously that kind of evidence. Nevertheless, there are submissions and letters that have come from many people who are prepared to put their name to the accusations they are making, if you like. I have to say that there is a tremendous concern represented by all of those industry groups and all of the individuals who have contacted my office, and I am sure Senator Mackay's office and no doubt Mrs Kernot's office as well.

There is tremendous concern out there. That is why we are appealing to the government at this point. We are saying to the government, `Look, you really cannot jump too quickly on this one. You really would be doing yourself a great service to agree to this disallowance.' As Senator Mackay has so eloquently said, we want the government to come back to us with some real proposals. This minister is also the minister for regional Australia. I would not want to say anything about his ability to represent regional Australia. There is no doubt about his commitment to it. He does care about regional Australia, but whether we can always agree on how services should be developed is another issue.

In all of this, one of the points made to me is how regional airports have been affected. I have three examples. The first is Maroochy airport in Queensland. Great concern exists there about the whole issue of the privatisation of air traffic control. A whole debate has gone on between the Maroochy Shire Council and the private operators of training schools at Maroochy airport who are very concerned about the problem they have with the new landing fees. They want to know whether, in the event that air traffic control services are privatised, it will mean greater costs. That is their concern.

The second example is the airport at Coffs Harbour in New South Wales from where a great stack of submissions on exactly the same issue have come. The third example—and Senator Eggleston, I know, is very concerned about this issue because he himself has had conversations with me about it—is the airport at Port Hedland, Western Australia, and problems there. So going from Queensland to New South Wales, and I am sure to Tasmania, and certainly to Western Australia—in fact, to every state—the same concerns are being raised.

The issue of air safety is one that every Australian who flies is concerned about. There is not a lot of confidence out there. Too many questions are being raised and not answered. As Senator Mackay said, in the estimates hearing we had a most remarkable day: in the blue corner, we had Dick Smith; in the red corner, we had Airservices and BASI—and I am not sure whether some of the senators were referees or in the fight. But it was a fascinating day. It was all to do with who was to blame, who was going to take the blame and who was being snowed by whom. It was just amazing.

I have to say that, out there in aviation customer land, people are very concerned. We cannot go ahead with this proposal unless the government does far more work on it. And today, just to further underline the concern that is out there, there have been media stories about toxic fumes in aircraft. I suppose all of us in this place have a vested interest in this matter because we fly on those BAE146s; they are used on the direct flight from Brisbane to Canberra. So there we have the thought that there might be pilots who are unable to land those aircraft because they are too sick from those fumes—if it is indeed the fumes that are causing the sickness.

All of these issues raise very serious questions about air safety and public health and we need to have these questions answered and these issues cleared up. I know that the government is taking some account of these matters, but its reaction time has just been too slow. I understand that this issue of toxic fumes has been around for 16 years; CASA at least has known about it for that long. It was only when it got wind that there were to be media reports about this on Friday that it finally decided to do something. So these are the problems.

Not only are we to vote now on this disallowance, but also there are at least two propositions for return to order, and both the Democrats and Labor are proposing that there be inquiries into a number of issues, which I hope will also be supported. So, Mr Acting Deputy President, we just cannot proceed with the regulations which are being proposed, statutory rules 1998 No. 234, without a pause. This disallowance motion gives the government, and indeed all of us, an opportunity to pause, reconsider and get all the facts on the table.

talk.start.para: —These regulations provide, as we know, for the privatisation of air traffic control services in Australia. They represent just another step by this government to privatise at all costs. It is a path this government has followed since it came to power in March 1996. These regulations also provide a clear illustration of how this government goes about its business—not in an open way, not in a considered way, but as quietly and as privately as possible. It has chosen in this area not to seek to win the support of the community for a particular policy change with the merits of its case; rather, it seeks to change policy by regulation and present the public with a fait accompli.

speech.para: An answer to a question on notice from Mr Tanner, the member for Melbourne, on this very matter makes the point that I seek to make. The answer appeared in Hansard on 14 May last year. Mr Tanner asked whether Airservices was proposing to privatise air traffic control. The answer reads as follows:
I am not aware of any substantive discussions between airport lessee companies and Airservices on this issue.

That is a slippery answer, to say the least, but it is true to form from this government generally, and the minister in particular, on this sort of matter. Less than four weeks later in an estimates hearing, we got the facts from Mr Bill Pollard, Chief Executive of Air services Australia, when he told the committee:
We are looking at the possibility of someone else providing air traffic control services in Australia at the smaller locations.

That evidence was given four weeks after the minister's answer to the question on notice to which I referred—Mr Tanner's question. Mr Pollard then tried to give the minister some protection by saying that Airservices had not had any substantive discussions on privatisation. Mr Quinlivan, who also gave evidence at the estimates hearing, then advised that the department and Airservices had conducted a structural review of air services. He said:
That review considered the alternative supply of air traffic services.

Mr Quinlivan also confirmed that the minister had been provided with a copy of the report that flowed from the Airservices Australia review. He said that the department had had discussions with the owners of privatised airports about the transfer of air traffic services to them. Despite the minister's attempt to mislead Mr Tanner in that answer, we now know the extent of the work that has gone on and the minister's role in that work. It is very clearly on the public record.

Airservices Australia and its predecessors have provided quality and safe air traffic control systems to the aviation industry and to the wider community. Errors have been made, but generally we have been very well off in this country when it comes to aviation safety. However, since the election, this government has sought to lower those standards and the worldwide reputation we enjoy when it comes to air safety. The standards are under threat. This plan to privatise air traffic services presents yet another significant threat to these standards.

In many smaller locations around Australia, the combination of privatised airports, location specific charges and now privatised air traffic services provide a dangerous cocktail for a reduction in safety standards. General aviation airports, such as Moorabbin, Bankstown, Archerfield, Parafield and Jandakot, are the busiest in Australia. They are used predominantly by numbers of inexperienced pilots undergoing training. These airports require a safe and high quality air traffic control service. Frankly, it is the government that has the responsibility to ensure that those services are there. If the government proposed action—and this regulation is the means by which it would act—succeeds with the privatisation plan, then the safety at those airports will be under threat.

Yet another example of how this government is downgrading safety has just come to my attention. In answer to a question on notice dated 20 October 1997, the member for Barton asked the then Minister for Transport, Mr Vaile, whether or not weather conditions preclude the safe operation of westerly take-offs from runway 25, the east-west runway at Sydney airport. The answer was yes. Mr Vaile advised that the runway was unsafe to use `when the crosswind component on the runway exceeds 20 knots and/or the downwind component exceeds five knots.' There is also an International Civil Aviation Organisation recommendation relating to landing in crosswinds. ICAO has recommended that compliance with published noise abatement procedures should not be required in `adverse operating conditions' such as when `the cross-wind component including gusts exceeds 15 knots'.
A Bureau of Air Safety Investigation's report concerning air safety operations at Sydney airport dated August last year stated:
A recent landing accident at Amsterdam involving a Boeing 757 has highlighted the risk of continued operations on runways with cross-winds of up to 25 knots.
In that incident the aircraft veered off the runway whilst flight crew were attempting to land in crosswinds. The BASI report said:

. . . whilst this level of cross-wind is within the structural capacity of the aircraft and the capacity of flight crews, it has reduced the margin for error when aircraft are required to land on close set parallel or short runways, when safer options are available. In addition, an increased level of complexity is added to the airspace environment when flight crews operationally require a landing on an into-wind runway while cross-wind operations are in progress, thus compromising structured airspace concepts.

However, we now find things have changed. I asked a question on 24 November last year about that BASI report and the use of the east-west runway. I wanted to know what Airservices Australia had done in response to the BASI finding that the use of runway 25 reduced safety margins. Only today I received the reply. The answer from the minister representing Minister Anderson, Senator Macdonald, advised that Airservices Australia consulted CASA in its review of the crosswinds policy in Sydney. There was no reference in the answer to Airservices Australia consulting with BASI.

The answer confirms that risk increases with increasing crosswind. It confirms the ICAO standard that for noise abatement purposes 15 knots is the maximum recommended crosswind, and it also states the same limit for operational purposes and noise abatement purposes is acceptable. It then states that the limit is 25 knots. So we have an ICAO recommended limit for noise abatement of 15 knots. We have the then minister, Mr Vaile, telling us in December 1997 that the weather conditions preclude the safe operation of runway 25 when the crosswind component reaches 20 knots, and we have a BASI report saying that 25 knots, while technically possible for both aircraft and crew, compromises safety. That is, the use of this runway in those conditions erodes the safety margin.

Now we have Airservices saying, `Yes, we know about the BASI concerns. We have talked to CASA, not BASI.' They say that it does not impose an unacceptable safety hazard. This policy has changed. It has changed despite BASI's concerns to the contrary. The minister said in his answer that if any pilots were worried about the safety of runway 25 in crosswinds they can use another runway. He knows full well the pressures that pilots are under. He knows that, if a pilot chose not to use runway 25, he or she would have to go to the end of a long queue, at Sydney airport in particular, and that would not be an acceptable option. It is the policy applied for the use of this runway that must be right. Give pilots an opt-out clause that in no way runs a risk to the safety regime at the major airports.

So, in addition to the disallowance of the regulation that we are debating to privatise air traffic services and the erosion of standards applying to the use of the east-west runway at Sydney airport, we now have the government seeking to transfer noise management responsibilities to the Sydney airport authority. In a letter which was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald over the weekend to Qantas, Ansett and the Sydney Airport Corporation, the chief executive of Airservices, Mr Pollard, said that his organisation had taken too much flak over the airport's long-term operating plan. And he said in the letter that Airservices does not own the airport, does not fly the planes nor does it control the weather that frequently dictates flight path configurations. But he does control air traffic control services, and that service determines traffic movements.

The government has made an absolute mess of the management of noise around Sydney airport. It has failed because it has sought a political objective by trying to shift noise from politically sensitive conservative seats to politically expendable Labor seats. It has ignored the option of seeking to minimise the noise impact on the greatest number of people living around KSA, and that strategy has now clearly failed.

So here we have a government which is trying to shift the blame to someone else. And the latest move by Airservices Australia on behalf of the government, I am sure, is just one more step down a very dangerous path—that is, a continuing process by the government of reducing its involvement in the provision of safe aviation services in this country. Unfortunately, if this process continues, a desire for profit will gradually override the desire to maintain our current high safety standards, and I fear we will pay a terrible price.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I suggested to Senator Mackay when she was delivering her speech that she should write a book. And I think she should get Senator O'Brien to join her because the speeches from both of the Labor Party senators were very interesting, quite entertaining, but very, very inaccurate—the sort of fantasy stuff you might read in a storybook being written for entertainment value and for a bit of `gee-whizzery' reaction.
—Lindsay Tanner.

—Lindsay Tanner's I think was an accurate book, Senator O'Chee. The speeches delivered by the two Labor Party senators would seem to be pure fantasy, pure story telling. Can I ask the two senators from the Labor Party a question? I understand Senator Mackay has a response, and I would very much like to hear why the Labor Party are opposed to this position when the Air Services Act of 1995—note that is when the Labor Party was in power—at section 11(3) says:

speech.para: (3) Where AA may provide a facility or service, it may do so:
(a) itself;
(b) in cooperation with another person (including the Commonwealth); or
(c) by arranging for another person (including the Commonwealth) to do so on its behalf.

That is Labor Party legislation that actually went through the parliament under a Labor Party minister and was voted for by the Labor Party. What we are doing in the regulations is almost word for word for that. You obviously have not read the regulation, Senator, and whoever has given you that speech to read has sold you the dump, I would suggest respectfully, because our regulation simply puts into effect what the Labor government legislated for in 1995.

Can I just read the regulation, because it is fairly obvious that you have not. It has one simple clause. It say that you will delete the definition of air traffic service and substitute this definition of air traffic services:
"Air Traffic Service means any of the following:
(a) AA in its capacity as the provider of air traffic services under subparagraph 8(1)(b)(i) of the Air Services Act 1995 ;—
the act that I just quoted to you—
(b) a person providing air traffic services in cooperation with AA for paragraph 11(3)(b) of that Act;
(c) a person providing air traffic services under an arrangement with AA for paragraph 11(3)(c) of that Act.".

It is putting into effect exactly what the Labor Party legislated for in 1995. I would be interested to know what has caused the change of heart of the Labor Party since 1995. It is your legislation under which this regulation is introduced, and the regulation simply puts into effect what your piece of legislation did. That to me smacks, at kindest, of simple story telling and, at worst, that you are simply in this to try to score a political point out of air safety. I think that really is what the Labor Party is all about today.

You pass legislation when you are in government and when we do exactly the same thing you suddenly change your mind and you oppose it for purely political purposes. Senator Mackay, I would like you to explain in your right of reply why it was good enough when you were in power and why, now that we are implementing your act by way of regulation, you suddenly find it no good.

I might say to Senator Woodley, who kindly said that I had an interest in regional services—and I do, Senator Woodley, and thank you for acknowledging that—that it is very simply because of my interest in regional services and because of my determination to make sure that regional airports continue to have air traffic control services at a reasonable price that I support this regulation. Senator, that is what it is all about. It is not about safety. It is not about privatising air services—quite to the contrary. It is about providing safety initiatives, safety services, for regional airports. Senator Woodley, can I say to you—and I hope Senator Mackay might be interested in this as a Tasmanian senator; and I see Senator Denman here as a Tasmanian senator and my colleague Senator Newman—that unless we are able—

talk.start.para: —There is another Tasmanian senator here.
—And Senator Harradine. I beg your pardon.
—And Senator O'Brien.
—We are all here.
—Order!
—I am sorry, I had not realised Senator O'Brien was from Tasmania; and now I have Senator Calvert as well from Tasmania—so we have all the elements. Are there any Democrats from Tasmania?

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—No.

talk.start.para: —Okay—Tasmanians showed some sense. Let me emphasise that, unless we are able to do something about reducing costs and getting private contractors under the auspices and control of Airservices Australia, landing charges for Tasmanian airports will increase. I happen to have a couple of examples of that for Senator Mackay's benefit. The current charge per tonne is $6.75. Unless we are able to get a cheaper service, that charge will have to go up to $7.49 per tonne. In Launceston the current charge of $6.75 per tonne will have to go up to $9.66 per tonne. Senator, what is that going to do to the people that you represent? It will mean that charges in Tasmania will go up dramatically because the subsidy runs out at the end of next year. It cannot be continued under the budgetary constraints. In fact, under the court case Airservices Australia v. Monarch Airlines, it was indicated that those charges had to be recovered from the users. So the difficulty is that for regional airports—I named two and there are a number of others right around Australia—prices will have to go up unless we can get a better way of doing it.

speech.para: I re-emphasise that there is a fundamental misunderstanding about the intention of the amendment to this regulation. I want to state categorically that it is not about privatisation of Airservices Australia. That misunderstanding is largely the result of material distributed by Civil Air, the union representing air traffic controllers. Nor is it a question about safety. Under the proposed amendments, Airservices will retain control of the service provider and will continue to apply current safety standards. I hope you understand that, Senator, because Airservices Australia will retain control—I repeat that— and it will continue to apply current safety standards.

The question is one of providing tower services at regional airports at reasonable cost. The amendment will permit organisations other than Airservices to provide for air traffic services under contract, exactly as your government intended when it passed the Air Services Act back in 1995. This means that while Airservices retains the regulatory responsibility of providing air traffic control services, someone with better flexibility in their cost structure than Airservices, with lower overheads, or who is able to operate at different hours, would provide air traffic control services at an individual tower. But I repeat that the act will still require that the standard of provision of this service would be that of Airservices Australia itself.

talk.start.para: —Like Sydney Airport.

—I can only repeat that it was your government, Senator, that recognised the possibility that Airservices would contract out air traffic services and the Act specifically allows, in the section that I have read out, for Airservices to either provide the air traffic services itself, in cooperation with another organisation, or to arrange for another organisation to provide the services on its behalf. Your Act said that, so why the change of heart? Our regulation puts into effect your legislation.

speech.para: In entering into any arrangements with another organisation, Airservices would still be bound by the requirements in the Act that require Airservices to regard the safety of air navigation as the most important consideration in exercising its powers and performing its functions. These regulations will enable owners and operators of airports to use organisations other than Airservices to provide air traffic services. This should allow airports to address the cost of their control towers, which the industry has subsidised for many years and which the government is currently subsidising heavily in an $11 million annual budget contribution.

It is important to understand that the number of organisations with expertise to provide these services is pretty limited. They are highly qualified and experienced and they are certainly not fly-by-night operators. The main operators at this stage would be Serco, an organisation with experience in providing these services in the United Kingdom, and any Airservices air traffic controllers presently providing these services at airports who choose to form a corporation of their own for that purpose. So there is really only those two groups—either Serco or the current air traffic controllers who want to go out and establish their own business. There are also flow-on benefits if the opportunity for alternative service providers is opened. Serco intends to use the option available under these regulations to set up an international training centre in Australia. If these regulations are disallowed, this opportunity for new business in Australia will be lost.

To fully understand the implications of disallowing this regulation, consideration needs to be given to the current situation at general aviation and smaller regional airports. It is vital, I suggest to you, Senator, that we understand which airports will be most affected by any decision to disallow these regulations. The currently subsidised airports are capital city general aviation centres, which are, as you know, major centres for small aviation businesses; Tasmanian airports—I hope you understand that; and regional airports in rural New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. That concerns me, both as a regional person and as the minister with responsibility for regional Australia.

Airservices has introduced charges for its services, including tower services in regional areas, which are based on costs it incurs at each location. The Federal Court has ruled that Airservices must take this approach—I mentioned previously the Airservices Australia v. Monarch Airlines case.

Without the subsidy or the changes to the cost structure at individual towers, there would need to be huge increases in the charges to pay for tower services. As I mentioned, charges at Hobart airport would have to increase from $6.75 to $7.49 per tonne, an increase of some 11 per cent. Charges at Launceston would have to increase from $6.75 to $9.66 per tonne, an increase of 43 per cent. Senator, your proposal to disallow these regulations would be a great blow to Tasmania because those charges will increase and add to the cost of all Tasmanians. Why are you wanting to penalise the people you are supposed to be representing?

In contrast, the government's approach differs significantly in that we will offer very significant savings for the Australian aviation industry and for rural and regional communities. Already Serco has indicated that it can provide as effective a service at a price significantly lower than that presently charged by Airservices at a number of locations. New airport operators have approached the government seeking to open up this option. They know that this is a process which has for many years operated successfully overseas, and I give the example of the FAA in the United States.

Senator, these regulations will not affect air safety at regional airports because Airservices Australia will still be in charge of the air safety regime at the airports. The regulations will ensure that the charges be maintained at an affordable level. Regrettably, your approach would greatly increase the cost of air travel for Australians, like me and you, who live in rural and regional areas. For those reasons, I think it is vital that we allow Airservices Australia this flexibility.

I conclude by saying that this regulation puts into effect what the Labor Party legislated for in 1995. Unfortunately, I do not have the voting slip in front of me to tell me who voted for that Airservices legislation in 1995. Senator Woodley might remember whether the Democrats supported it. I suspect they probably did. I suspect that the current government also supported the Labor Party proposal to do this, because it made sense. It made sense to the Labor government of the day and it makes sense to us. If you can get a cost-effective service into aviation, then you should do it. Otherwise, regional travellers, like me and the Tasmanian senators, will have to pay more. There is an alternative. I urge the Senate to reject this motion so that regional travellers can have those cheaper services but in a way that is absolutely safe because Airservices Australia will still maintain the overall regime of safety.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I will not take long.
—You have 20 minutes.

—I may have 20 minutes, but I will not take that time, fortunately for the chamber. There are a couple of things I want to rebut in relation to the submission from the minister, who has become an expert on Airservices Australia in about three hours and 20 minutes. In question time today he had some vague memory about a letter from Mr Pollard, who is CEO of Airservices Australia, but not enough to answer any questions in relation to it. That issue went to the heart of air safety. Mr Pollard was saying that it was all too hard in relation to Sydney airport, that the safety regime was too difficult for Airservices Australia, and he was suggesting that the whole box and dice be given back to Sydney airport. How can we accept a guarantee from the minister when we have this tangible example in front of us that Airservices Australia are basically flying the white flag and saying, `It is too difficult for us'? This is what is happening at the moment at Sydney airport.

speech.para: Senator Macdonald made much of the Labor Party's legislation. That was there for a very good reason. I am surprised he did not understand the nature of the reason, which was to allow the RAAF to provide services in Darwin, for example. It was never intended to precipitate the full privatisation of air traffic control in Australia. If it were, why on earth have this regulation in the first place? Why come into the chamber with a regulation? Why not just go with the legislation? Why do they need to do this? The answer is very obvious: the legislation from this government's point of view is clearly insufficient to ensure that there is full privatisation of air traffic control. Therefore, they need the clarification of the regulation in order to do it.

The other fairly astounding thing from Senator Macdonald was the issue of prices going up in regional airports. There is a very easy way for Senator Macdonald to rectify that—that is, keep the subsidy going.

talk.start.para: —Do you want to put up taxes?

—I remind Senator Macdonald of the many comments by Mr Costello about the size of the budget surplus to the extent that this government is able to fund massive tax cuts to high income people. So why not use some of the budget surplus to keep the subsidy going for regional airports? Why not do that, rather than give massive tax cuts to people who do not need it?

speech.para: The other interesting point I wish to comment on briefly is Senator Macdonald's assertion that air safety will not be compromised at all by this new regime. If air safety is not to be compromised, how will the savings be made? The illogical conclusion of this regulation is that virtually anybody could provide air traffic control. That is something I do not think one person in Australia wants. I do not think one person in Australia wants one iota more of safety to be removed from the whole regime of air safety in Australia, certainly not by the privatisation of air traffic control, which I notice was not denied either by Minister Anderson or Minister Macdonald here today.

Senator Macdonald went into some detail with regard to one of the groups that is looking at the provision of services—that is, Serco. I have to say that is more information than we have ever got before. Senator Woodley is nodding in agreement. That is more information than we have ever got before in relation to exactly what this is going to mean. The government comes in here, through Senator Macdonald, and, in defending its actions, without the transparency of amending legislation or whatever, gives a lot more detail about the privatisation of air traffic control and Serco's activities than we have ever had before.

I think that pretty much QED proves our point—that is, too much has been done by regulation in relation to the activities of this government. If this government really wants to privatise air traffic control, which it clearly does, it should not have done it by the promulgation of the regulation. It should have come in here with a proper amendment to legislation, so that it could be fully debated, so that we could refer it to a legislation committee, which Senator Woodley, me and others are on, so that we can look at it, so that we can get submissions from interested parties and so on, and so we don't have a situation that we have at the moment whereby Airservices Australia is saying that air safety at Sydney airport is too difficult for it.

We do not want a repeat of what has happened elsewhere. We do not want a repeat of the situation in the US, where they are having to relook at this entire situation. They are having to consider revisiting their initiatives in relation to this area because of concerns about air safety. I thank Senator Macdonald for his contribution in strengthening our case in relation to opposing the privatisation of air traffic control. I do not think our case has been dented one bit. I would also like to thank other senators for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (YOUTH EMPLOYMENT) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —When the debate on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Youth Employment) Bill 1998 was adjourned before question time I was raising a question as to why the urgency for the introduction of this legislation, given that the matter had been referred under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to an inquiry by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Such inquiry is due to report to the minister by June of this year. Obviously one has to come to the conclusion that the introduction of this legislation is a blatant attempt by the minister to circumvent the outcomes of the AIRC inquiry.

speech.para: If the minister wanted to ignore the inquiry, if he felt that the inquiry was not going to bring down a set of findings that would allow him to run the sort of agenda he wants to run, which he spelt out in the letter he sent to the Prime Minister and in the speech he made to Freehill, Hollingdale and Page in February of this year, then clearly he could have introduced legislation here which would have amended the Workplace Relations Act and abolished the inquiry altogether. Instead of that he has seen fit to introduce legislation in here dealing with the question of youth wages while, parallel, the Industrial Relations Commission is looking at the whole issue and is due to report to the minister in June of this year.

Once again, this demonstrates that this government and this minister in particular are not driven by a desire to implement good policy. They are not driven by a desire to put policies in place that will benefit the section of the community those policies are supposed to be targeted at. They are driven by an ideological agenda, a political agenda, which has as much to do with the minister's ambitions to be Prime Minister of this country as it has to do with trying to get young people into employment.

The message is clear in the letter to the Prime Minister. The minister clearly spells out the government's agenda for cutting youth wages, for keeping the wages of young people down. He again spells it out in the paper to Freehill, Hollingdale and Page in February this year. That agenda is a key focus of both those documents. The government's whole agenda on wages from when they came to power—despite the rhetoric they put before the Australian people in 1995, and in 1996 prior to the election about no worker in this country being worse off—has been exactly to achieve that. Their whole political strategy, their legislative strategy, is about setting in place the circumstances to cut real wages in this country, to create the same sorts of circumstances that apply in many countries overseas—to create a class of working poor. Young people are a part of that target in the wages agenda of this government.

It is as if a panacea has suddenly arrived—that if we keep the wages of young people down, if their wages are less than we pay to adults, then they will suddenly get employment because we will create jobs. I think the minister referred somewhere to 300,000 new jobs being created for young people in the current situation—a view that has been utterly rejected by both the ACTU and AYPAC.

But the reality is that junior rates of pay are not the problem in terms of unemployment of young people. If they were, then the problem would be easily resolvable. I will just give you an example in my own state. In the 12 months to December 1998, the average full-time youth unemployment rate in the Illawarra statistical district was 27.9 per cent. In the Richmond/Tweed/Mid North Coast statistical district, the rate was even higher—35.8 per cent. In comparison, adult unemployment for the month of December 1998 was 10.9 per cent in the Illawarra and 12.9 per cent in Richmond/Tweed/Mid North Coast. The reality is that, if young people worked for nothing in both those districts, you would not create enough jobs to significantly reduce the unemployment level. It is a nonsense to suggest it.

Over the past decade or so, as a result of structural changes in the economy, many entry level jobs have disappeared out of our economy. The number of apprenticeships and traineeships have fallen. The number of job opportunities in the banking industry and the finance sector—which was a major employer of young people—have gone. They have been displaced by technological change, privatisation and corporatisation and a contraction of the public sector. Through structural change, we have abolished thousands and thousands of what were essentially job opportunities for young people, and they have not been replaced within our economy.

It is also true to say that those structural changes in our economy that occurred right throughout the 1980s and the 1990s occurred in conjunction with the application of junior rates of pay. The fact that junior rates of pay applied under our award system through the 1980s and the 1990s did not help to alleviate the impact of structural change on job opportunities for young people. Growing unemployment amongst young people continued throughout the 1980s and the 1990s because of that structural change and not because of any significant shift in the rates of pay that young people were paid over that period. It is a fallacy to suggest that somehow or other keeping pay rates at a lower level is going to all of a sudden contribute to a huge demand or a groundswell for employment of young people in the community.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator McGauran, you will have your opportunity to get on your feet and demonstrate exactly how the young people are going to be employed. Show us where the 300,000 new jobs for young people are going to be created in this economy as a result of your policy on youth wages. You get up and demonstrate it, and I will listen intently to your contribution, because it will be just as hollow as every other contribution you have made in this chamber since you have been a senator.

speech.para: We continually get bombarded in this place with political rhetoric saying, `If you only do this 50,000 new jobs will be created there, 100,000 new jobs will be created here, 300,000 new jobs will be created there.' None of it has been demonstrated. None of it has, in fact, been targeted in terms of where those actual jobs are or where they can be created as a result of these policy changes. I do not think we ought to spend too much time dealing with or being concerned about that type of rhetoric.

In the last 20 years, we have seen a fall of 18 per cent in real wages for young males and a fall of 12 per cent for young females. On the other hand, real wages for adult males and females have risen by seven and 12 per cent respectively. In fact, over the past decade, the gap in wages between young people and older adults has grown—the disparity has widened. Despite that fact, there are a greater number of young people unemployed today than 10 or 12 years ago—and, as I said previously, it has nothing to do with the issue of wages.

The 1997 inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training heard from Ms Felicity Thomson of the Queensland Retail Traders and Shopkeepers Association. In relation to subsidies to encourage employment, she said:

I definitely find that most employers are not interested in the fact that they have to pay a salary . . . they are more interested in getting the right person for the job in the long run and whether that person is going to perform to the standards they require.

That argument, I would suggest, is just as valid with respect to the question of junior rates of pay. It is, in fact, strengthened by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in its own publication, Review , of December 1998 in an article entitled `Youth Employment and Junior Rates' in which it said that, in a survey by ACCI of 400 businesses, the reasons given for employing juniors were: preference to train their own employees—of major importance, 27.4 per cent; willingness of juniors to do certain types of work—18 per cent; and lower wages for juniors—third on the list at 17.5 per cent. So wages is not the determining factor in decisions by employers to employee juniors—to put juniors on.

In a press released dated 5 September 1998, the minister says he believes that by encouraging junior rates of pay, more young people will be employed, giving more of them a `toehold in the labour market. Without them, young people would be competing against more experienced adults for jobs—they would be squeezed out and left with little opportunity for getting a start in life.' That is very clearly not the case.

AYPAC, the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, agrees with the position of the Labor Party: there is no evidence to suggest that young people's jobs will be jeopardised if the Senate votes against this bill—no evidence at all. It is interesting to note, however, that funding for AYPAC, the peak national youth affairs body, was cancelled in December 1998. Further, AYPAC has been denied observer status at Dr David Kemp's national youth round table as the organisation has criticised government policy in the past. It appears that, as soon as a lot of community organisations express a point of view that is not consistent with the policy agenda of this government, all of a sudden they seem to have real difficulties in getting funding to continue their operation. It appears that funding decisions by this government to community organisations are not predicated upon the contribution those organisations are making in the community but upon whether or not they are prepared to toe the policy line of the government.

The reality is that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is conducting an inquiry into the question of youth rates. That inquiry has been going on just on two years. It has had a wide range of submissions to it in terms of what ought to be done in the area of youth wages. There are a variety of proposals, as I understand it, that have been put before that inquiry of ways and means to deal with this question. It may well be that that inquiry will find that there is more than one way to skin the cat in terms of this issue; there are a variety of mechanisms that can be applied to deal with the questions of wages, wage rates, wage relativities of young people in employment, which go to the question of skills and training and the type of policy settings that were adopted by the Labor Party when it was in government in terms of the youth trainee wages, which is one element of the process.

It appears that the inquiry's outcomes or findings have already been prejudged by this government. They are not concerned to have the views of an unbiased umpire. They are not concerned to listen to the findings of a group of people who have had a long period of experience in dealing with the issue of wage fixing, in dealing with the issue of industrial relations matters and in dealing with the issue of youth in employment. They are not concerned to try to understand the myriad of arguments that have been put before that inquiry or to look at the suggested outcomes that that independent tribunal may come up with in terms of dealing with these issues.

The minister has already circumvented the inquiry. He circumvented it some six months ago. He has not shown the slightest bit of interest in what the independent umpire might find in terms of how to address this issue. Why? Because this government has got an ideological bent against workers. It has got an ideological bent against their organisation. It has an agenda that is driven by serving the needs of capital, which the minister himself has said his agenda is, that is his only purpose for being here. It is driven by a desire to cut real wages. No-one in this community across the spectrum believes any longer in the rhetoric of 1996 that no worker would be worse off in this country, because there are thousands and thousands of examples out there in the community that repudiate that statement of the Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —Real wages have gone up.

—It is true real wages have gone up. What feeds into that? The huge boost in executive salaries. Don't you know how average wages are calculated in this community?
