Outside of metropolitan areas, exorbitant connection costs and low bandwidth resulting in low quality service present a real barrier to many who seek to use the Internet, despite the fact that connectivity is clearly the key to creating regional employment opportunities and economic growth. It is for this reason alone that the level of access to the Internet for women in 1998 stood at only 21 per cent.

There is no doubt that the issue of access, and equity of access, to the Internet is one of the primary social policy challenges of the next century. Not to address this in a forthright and confronting way will be to produce a society of information haves and have-nots, with the resultant economic and social division that will entrench itself.

The ascendancy of the Internet also marks a turning point for modern society, a tangible generational change. We see many baby boomers reaching retirement age and decision making in our society is no longer the domain of, or indeed captive to, old guard misogynists. Young women have the opportunity now more than ever to map out the goals and objectives that they believe are worth fighting for. With growing numbers being represented in this place, and with the support of infrastructure and the society within which they are placed, women stand to lead this nation in an ever-increasing range of endeavours.

The Internet gives young leaders the opportunity to bypass the conservative establishment's pre-determined channels of communication. It will give a voice to youth culture, human rights activists and environmentalists the world over. It allows global movements to work cooperatively at a local level like never before. The turn of the millennium is therefore an opportunity to skip ahead in the attitude stakes and relegate sexism and misogyny to a 20th century `what's out' list.

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to follow on from Senator Lundy's speech commemorating, among other things, International Women's Day. I also rise to speak on the issue of IWD.

speech.para: The idea for a national women's day came about at the turn of the last century when, in accordance with a declaration by the Socialist Party of America, the first National Women's Day was observed in the United States on 28 February 1909. The following year the Socialist International meeting in Copenhagen, a conference of more than 100 women from 17 countries, established a women's day—to be celebrated across the world—to honour the women's movement and to assist in the campaign for universal suffrage. This day was celebrated for the first time on 19 March in Austria, Germany, Denmark and Switzerland when more than one million men and women attended rallies demanding the right for women to vote, to be able to hold public office, to participate in education and training and to work free from discrimination.

While the idea of a day of commemoration of the women's movement is only around 100 years old, the origins of the struggle of women for equality are ancient—yet they are as relevant today as they were, some would say, centuries ago. The women's movement can be traced back many centuries; indeed, we could go back as far as classical Greece where Lysistrata initiated a sexual strike against men to end war—and those in the chamber who are aware of their classical studies would know that story only too well.

Today women around the world campaign for social justice and to bring about an end to discrimination. They do that through varying ways and techniques—and Senator Lundy has just mapped out a very present, but also future, way of achieving change through an increasingly democratic medium, that of the Internet.

Tonight, if I get time, obviously I will touch on women's participation in a range of areas and sectors and professions. But I would begin by looking at women in the political arena, women in leadership positions. We have yet to assume our fair share of leadership roles in this country, but that is not to say we have not had a number of female pioneers.

The first women to stand for election in the country was Catherine Helen Spence, from my home state of South Australia. She ran for the National Australasian Convention prior to the turn of the century and came 22nd in a candidate field of 33. She was not elected in 1897, but a century on I think she remains an inspiration on state, national and international levels. More than 100 years on from Catherine Helen Spence's electoral defeat, women comprise only 21.4 per cent—that is around one in five—of members of the parliament. This is one of our best results yet, so we have still got a way to go.

In almost 100 years we have seen 25 men in the position of Prime Minister; not one woman has attained that position yet. The laws of probability are stacked against this result, but the laws of patriarchy have weighed the balance strongly in its favour. One could assume from this statistic that politics is either not very scientific or is not a good bet for Australian women. In truth, it is neither at present. However, Australian politics are still a far better bet for Australian women than for many of our international sisters. While there is certainly a great deal of improvement needed in our country, our representative levels are something like double the international average when it comes to women's participation. Indeed, Australia has some reasons to be proud of our her story of political women and our role in the journey towards political equality.

In politics and in public policy, Australia has often led the way. While many would be aware that Australia led the way in the fight for women's suffrage, when in 1894 South Australia became one of the first places in the entire world to grant women not only the right to vote but also the right to stand for parliament, I imagine some people would share my surprise in noting that the word `femocrat', like the Hills Hoist, is also an Australian invention. In the parliamentary web site, I note that there is reference to the fathers of the house. Tonight I would like to pay tribute to some of the mothers of the house. These are women who have achieved significant firsts in our parliamentary herstory, and they include the Hon. Joan Child, who became the first female Speaker of the House of Representatives in 1986. Madam President, I pay due deference to you, the first female President of the Senate. You join Senator Sue West in an all female leadership team.

I am particularly proud that in 1986 the Australian Democrats led the way with the election of Senator Janine Haines as the first woman to lead an Australian parliamentary party, an achievement reflected three years later in the states and territories when Rosemary Follett from the ACT became the first female to head a government, an achievement followed by the Hon. Joan Kirner in Victoria and Carmen Lawrence in WA in 1990. In the law, women have made other achievements. In 1987 Mary Gaudron became the first woman to be appointed to the High Court of Australia.

talk.start.para: —What about the achievements of Dame Enid Lyons or Annabelle Rankin?
—I hope dearly that Senator Macdonald will take on this theme because, as he so rightly interjects, there are many women all over on different sides of politics who have been—
—But apart from the President you did not mention one from the non-socialist side.

—For the information of the house, I was talking about the first women in those positions. I am sure that Senator Macdonald does not mean to impute those particular women or their party status in any way. We have mentioned a number of women from different political parties. I hope that he does not seek to reflect in any negative or partisan way on tonight's celebration of International Women's Day. In 1990 Deidre O'Connor became the first female Federal Court judge and president of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In 1991 the Law Institute of Australia appointed Gail Owen as the first president in its 132-year history.

speech.para: As a passionate republican, many of whom are in this chamber tonight, I believe we have a great opportunity to right some of the wrongs in errors of our past through that particular discourse. Unlike the women of this nation, denied the opportunity to participate in the Federation and constitutional debates some 100 years before, last year I and other women were proud to take our places as delegates at the Constitutional Convention alongside women like Lowitja O'Donoghue, Poppy King, Janet Holmes a Court, Misha Schubert, Mia Handshin, Nova Peris-Kneebone and Heidi Zwar. A number of younger and older and certainly diverse Australians were represented at the Constitutional Convention.

These women were all compelling advocates for an Australian republic. Heidi Zwar was not a republican, but I think she deserves acknowledgment as a young woman being involved. They were all in favour of a new era of liberty, egality and fraternity but also sorority. The choice of a woman as the first head of state is something that I personally think would symbolise our move into the next century as a nation committed to equality between sexes. It is appropriate that we progress from the system of a monarchy, a system which is essentially patriarchal, and embrace the system where it does not matter whether a person is male or female to be a head of state—that is, a republic. Gender equality must be placed at the top of the agenda if we are to capture our full potential as a nation.

Politics and law are not the only places where women do not always get a fair go. Despite their prowess and success in the sporting arena, women are not treated equally to their male colleagues in that particular area of Australian life. In 1990, women's sports coverage in Australian newspapers stood at an abysmal two per cent. Between 1980 and 1996, this figure increased by 500 per cent, with women's sports attracting 10.7 per cent of newspapers' coverage. In the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, the proportion of medals won by female athletes was 44 per cent higher than their representation in the Australian team. I look forward to more balanced coverage in the 2000 Olympics.

In education, one of the most important tools for preparing girls and women, despite the gains of women participating in undergraduate and prior levels of education, they are still under-represented in higher and further education. Women are participating in undergraduate education in greater numbers than men, but then their participation drops off quite dramatically in postgraduate study, in particular in those courses that attract up-front fees.

In employment, there is still a lower status, prestige and pay attached to women's work, although equal pay for equal work was granted by the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in 1972. Despite that, women's earnings are still 84 per cent of men's full-time earnings. While we celebrate many gains tonight and today, and indeed as we progress to the next century, there are still some struggles, some battles, some campaigns left to be fought and resolved. I hope that all legislators, those currently serving and aspiring politicians, will take on board working for social justice and equality for women as part of their goals.

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that International Women's Day has provided the inspiration for many speeches during the day and in the Senate tonight. In the brief time that one has in an adjournment speech, it is wonderful to see the record of so many prominent Australian women mentioned.

speech.para: It is difficult to fit them all in, but who could seriously overlook the extraordinary achievement of Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who, of course, was the first ever woman cabinet minister. That is a pretty significant achievement. We have not yet had a female Prime Minister, but we on our side of the record are very proud of the fact that we have produced not only the first woman cabinet minister but also such an outstanding one. When you look at achievements in the judiciary, who could overlook the extraordinary achievements of Dame Roma Mitchell, who was the first woman appointed to any Supreme Court in Australia and who served her state and her country with such distinction and continues to do so. I just thought it fair to mention the fact that both sides of the record can produce outstanding women.

International Women's Day is a very important day both for men and for women and was celebrated almost a century ago, as Senator Stott Despoja mentioned. It is embraced by millions of women from all races, all walks of life and all political parties. It recognises and highlights the achievements of women in their struggle for equality, social justice and freedom, and its message proliferates further and with more resonance every year. It is as much a celebration of the past as it is for the future.

It is a rare opportunity that we get to really compliment all women in parliament. I want to commend the work and dedication of all the women in the Australian parliament. Women in politics, like women in all spheres of Australian life, face a raft of challenges and impediments and often have to perform at quite extraordinary levels to achieve what may seem unexceptional outcomes. The women of the Australian parliament, both past and present, should be proud of their achievements. Hopefully through our work we are able to encourage other women to enter political life, because our nation needs a parliament that is truly representative of Australian society—and we are not there yet.

Over the last week, women across Australia and across the world have been gearing up for International Women's Day in a number of ways, and I have been privileged enough to have been involved in some of these celebrations. I want to mention an important Australian initiative launched last Monday by the Australian Business Women's Network, Women's Business Week, which celebrates the success stories of 50 Australian business women from all over Australia and from a diversity of backgrounds.

Women's Business Week and the Business Women's Hall of Fame celebrate women's progress in the traditionally male dominated world of business, and there are some quite extraordinary stories. The Hall of Fame honours 50 inductees who have shown outstanding vision and drive and who have made opportunities for themselves as women where often opportunities did not exist. For many of them, it has been a hard slog, a fight to the top and a fight for recognition, and they have had to fight in a way that makes their achievements all the more remarkable.

Today I want not only to acknowledge, celebrate and salute the work of Australian women and the significance and importance of International Women's Day but also to comment on some of the more significant coalition achievements in this area where the government has been unjustly criticised. Over the last three years, the government has begun to comprehensively address the role women should be playing not only in society as a whole but also in parliament and in our governmental structures. Although significant progress has been made, it is important to note that there is still a great need on both sides of politics and from all sectors of the community to recognise and embrace the potential talent that women can offer Australia.

It is fair to say that, for too many years, both business and politics in particular have missed out on the potential talent of some 52 per cent of the population and are in need of a truly gender balanced work force. Why is it that women still comprise only 7.6 per cent of private sector boards, 9.7 per cent of non-executive directors and 1.3 per cent of executive directors? Why is the female participation rate in the Australian parliament still only 25.4 per cent when the United Nations has set 30 per cent as the benchmark for meaningful participation in a country's parliament?

These statistics, while they are encouraging, do paint a bit of a dismal picture when political equity has been recognised for a century. Is the principle of political equity rhetoric or reality? What is being done to close the all too obvious gender gap? Is Germaine Greer—love her or loathe her—correct in her assertion that the rhetoric of equality is being used in the name of political correctness to mask the hammering that some women are taking?

All these questions are still valid as we approach the new millennium—and, yes, I do think there are some answers. Women still face an uphill battle to attain true equality and true representation, and women still face fundamental conflicts—the balancing of work and family is still something that besets most women—that need to be adequately addressed if true equality is to be realised. However, the coalition must be commended for recognising this and working to resolve the all too prevalent gaps. The government has worked hard to identify and address the problems and issues faced by women and continues to remain committed to resolving them practically, sensibly and with energy and vigour.

I think it is encouraging to see that women now comprise one-third of small business operators and farm managers, and this number is increasing at a much faster rate than men. Women are also the winners in the coalition's tax package, with a proposal to extend the family tax initiative. This will increase the tax-free threshold for families and is worth an extra $490 a year to single income families—many of whom, of course, are women—with one child under five. Families with two working parents and one child under five will receive benefits worth an extra $140 a year.

The coalition's pledge to inject $25.3 million into domestic violence prevention strategies is a huge leap forward in recognition of this pervasive problem and will provide a lifeline to those women trapped in violent relationships, particularly those in isolated rural situations.

But I think, as indicated by the Prime Minister in question time today, that the coalition's greatest achievement and most significant step forward for women has been in the economy. We have got the economy humming like a well-tuned engine and this can be nothing but beneficial to all Australian women. The coalition has delivered lower interest rates and ensured that Australians now have more disposable income and thereby more choice. And if women are to achieve real and true equality then they must have choice. The coalition, through good economic management, has been able to provide many women with a range of choices that have not been available to them before.

Australian businesses also need to be not only encouraged but also commended for the way in which they have taken up affirmative action programs. It has not always been easy for businesses to see the value of promoting women within their organisations and a lot of credit for that is due to the brilliant and inspired directorship of Catherine Harris of the Affirmative Action Agency, who finished her term a week or so ago. Her practical commonsense and down-to-earth attitude really did promote the cause of women in many businesses.

Participation of women in the labour force has increased steadily but, despite equal pay decisions dating back to 1969, women still have not achieved real earning parity and the progress of women into management positions has been relatively slow. This is not acceptable, and we must admit that we have to do better. I can only agree with the United Nations that no enduring solution to society's most threatening problems can take place without the full empowerment of the world's women.

On this very special commemorative evening, I want to conclude my remarks by saluting the women of Australia—not only women in parliament, but the women of Australia. As some speakers have said tonight, together we are forging the Australia of the future, and I believe there is every reason to be proud.

talk.start.para: —The history of International Women's Day dates back to 1910 internationally and to 1928 in Australia, but socialist women in the United States organised the first national women's day in 1908 and helped to inspire the international event. This day has traditionally been seen as a time for asserting women's political and social rights, for reviewing the progress that women have made or, as a day of celebration. Tonight I would like to take this opportunity to talk about pioneer women in Australia and a little place in Alice Springs that is seeking to ensure that these women hold a place in our history and are not forgotten.

speech.para: A pioneer woman is considered to be any woman who was a pioneer in her chosen field, referring not only to the traditional meaning of the word as colonist, explorer or settler in a new land, but to anyone who is an innovator or developer of something new, who has striven to make a new path in their chosen career. We have heard many examples of that tonight. This means we should commemorate not only those women who were the early settlers in Australia and who battled considerable hardships but also those who have attained pioneering achievements and who have been the first in their field.

The National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame was established in Alice Springs in 1993. It is a museum of national importance that is not only unique in Australia, but unique in the world. This national project is dedicated to preserving women's place in history and their contribution to Australia's heritage. Only two similar women's museums exist in Australia. The Pioneer Women's Memorial Folk Museum near Brisbane and the pioneer women's hut at Tumbarumba in New South Wales, although both of these are more of a local or regional nature.

Why a national pioneer women's hall of fame and why in Alice Springs? Molly Clarke, a feisty central Australian pastoralist, was bitterly disappointed when she visited the Stockman's Hall of Fame to find that very few women pioneers were celebrated in this hall of fame. This lack of women being represented led to a public meeting being called in February only five years ago in 1993 to gain some interest in developing this hall of fame. It became an incorporated organisation or association in April 1993 and was launched at Molly's home at Oldandado Homestead, just 330 kilometres south-east of Alice Springs. A committee of 10 to 15 local people meet once a month to run the organisation and the hall of fame only remains open to the public through the efforts of volunteers.

In March 1994 the Museum of Art and Galleries of the Northern Territory leased the old courthouse to the organisation for five years. Finance to keep this project going has stemmed from membership fees, fund raising, donations or the sale of merchandise and the occasional grants from local council, the Northern Territory government and the National Preservation Office. In July 1996 the courthouse was closed for renovations and was re-opened on International Women's Day in 1997.

With its first professionally designed exhibition titled `Ordinary women, extraordinary lives, women first in their field'. This project was funded by a Northern Territory heritage grant. It displays 100 photographs and stories of pioneering women and houses a collection of historic women's work tools. It features women who were pioneers in over a dozen largely male dominated professions—academia, medicine, law, veterinary science, architecture, public service, politics at all levels, telecommunications, the film industry, aviation, the arts, the church and sport. Such an exhibition has never been compiled before in Australia and aims to inform, inspire and generally heighten the status of women.

Some of those women whose achievements are on display in the National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame in Alice Springs include: Constance Stone, Australia's first female registered medical practitioner who was refused entry to Melbourne University in 1884 and trained overseas; Florence Taylor who qualified in 1907 as Australia's first woman architect and had to wait 13 years before being permitted membership of the New South Wales Institute of Architects; Australia's first female Olympiads, Fanny Durack and Minnie Wylie, who were forced to pay their own way to Stockholm to compete in the 1912 games; Deborah Wardley the first woman to fly for a major airline; Rosie Cannuth Monks the first Aboriginal female star who, of course, played the role in Australia's first feature length film Jeda; Edith Cowan the first woman member of any Australian parliament; and Peg Christian the first veterinary surgeon to establish a private small animal practice in the Northern Territory.

The courthouse continues to be manned by over 50 volunteers who sit for four hours daily so the general public can enjoy the National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame. The NT Regional Museum has provided funding for their first salaried curator from October 1997 to June of last year. The organisation aims to have their own purpose-built museum and research centre in Alice Springs and are currently conducting a buy a brick campaign for the building fund to be established.

So why am I taking the trouble to raise this on International Women's Day? Mainly because we know that the Shearer's Hall of Fame in New South Wales recently received $6 million from the federal government and the Axeman's Hall of Fame in Tasmania has had similar support. Of course, we all know, as I have mentioned, about the Stockman's Hall of Fame in Longreach and their bicentennial funding. So I ask the federal government this question: isn't it time we commemorated the women who have contributed to the development of Australia? Isn't it time, after five years, that we recognised the commitment of these people and mainly women in Alice Springs in establishing the National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame? I call on the government on International Women's Day to recognise this museum and this monument and to fund it as much as they do the Shearer's Hall of Fame, the Axeman's Hall of Fame and the Stockman's Hall of Fame.

The National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame aims to inform, inspire and heighten the status of women in Australia. It is time that they were funded by the federal government. They commemorate women throughout Australia who were pioneers in their chosen field and collectively act to gather their stories, photographs and related artefacts. It is a new museum and a monument that we should be proud of. It is a museum and a hall of fame which does promote what ordinary women have done in Australia and how extraordinary their lives have contributed to the development of our country. So I say to the federal government: it is time that we commemorated the women who have contributed to the development of Australia and it is time that the federal government provided this group with the funds they need to continue to National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame in Alice Springs.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I rise very briefly to join my colleague Senator Coonan in recognising the great contribution women have made to public life in Australia. Perhaps I will start with you, Madam President, and your achievement, what you have done, as a senator for this territory but perhaps more importantly in your role as President of the Senate. I listened with interest to Senator Stott Despoja, who rattled off a list of prominent women. Apart from you, I do not think any of them were from anything but the left side of politics. I just wanted to mention Dame Enid Lyons, the first female federal MP and minister, and Senator the Hon. Dame Annabelle Rankin, who was the first minister federally in charge of a department and was also I am told the first female head of mission for the Australian diplomatic service.

speech.para: Who could talk about the contribution women have made without recognising the vibrant and very able current Chief Minister of this territory, a person with whom I have the pleasure and honour to deal in my role as minister for the territories. Of course I am very proud of Joan Sheldon, who was the first female leader of a political party in the Queensland state parliament. Who could forget the magnificent contribution that my friend Sallyanne Atkinson made to public life as mayor of perhaps Australia's largest—in area at least—city. I was surprised that Senator Stott Despoja had forgotten the contribution Sallyanne Atkinson had made.

In my role as minister for local government I come in contact very often with a great number of very committed Australians who happen to be women but who are also mayors of their communities. I recognise the head of the Northern Territory Local Government Association is a female. There are very significant mayors like Liz Cunningham in Queensland, who was the Mayor of Calliope, and Anne Portess, who is the Mayor of Herberton. I should not do this, because there are literally dozens and dozens of female mayors right throughout Australia and, by mentioning some, you obviously leave out others. But some that immediately spring to mind are the mayors of Broadsound, Beaudesert and Longreach in my state. There is also Mayor Joy Baluch from South Australia, who I have had some very interesting meetings with and who is a very significant and interesting person in her own right.

I also, not in recent times but in previous years, have been impressed by the number of women leaders—chairmen, mayors, presidents—of some of the community councils in Cape York who, under very difficult circumstances, have done magnificent work. Madam President, they, like you, have all made a major contribution to public life in Australia which is very much worth recognising today.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: British Commonwealth Occupation Force Veterans: Health Survey
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 15)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 November 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Will a health survey be conducted of former British Commonwealth Occupation Force (BCOF) veterans; if so, when will the survey commence; (b) has any representation been received from organisations representing BCOF veterans or from individuals requesting such a study be undertaken; and (c) will there be a review of the health status of personnel who participated in the Chemical Warfare Research and Experimental Unit's 1944 `Mustard Gas' north Queensland trials.

(2) Will a review be conducted of the position of those widows who are denied a war widows pension due to having remarried prior to 28 May 1984; if so, when will that review be conducted and what issues will it be considering.
(3) Have concerns been raised in the past 12 months relating to the operation of the department's office in Brisbane; if so, what were those concerns and what progress has been made to address them.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) No. There are no plans to carry out a health survey of BCOF veterans. My Department has, however, carried out research of a small number of veterans who were in Nagasaki on the day that the plutonium implosion bomb (known as "Fat Man") was exploded over Nagasaki. In August of 1945, unbeknown to allied forces, there were a number of Prisoners of War in and around the city of Nagasaki, including 27 Australians. Beginning in 1974, Professor P L T Ilbery, an expert in the field of the health effects of radiation, was commissioned by my Department to study the surviving veterans for evidence of radiation damage. By this stage, several had died, and only 21 were available for study. Of these, the research team regarded four as being not the subject of radiation, with 17 receiving some dose of ionising radiation. Of these, three were demonstrated to have chromosomal aberrations indicating radiation damage. The result of this research was published in the Journal of Radiation Research, Vol 18, pages 132-8, in 1977, in an article written by Professor Ilbery, writing with C A K Chee.

My Department has monitored the death rate of these 27 veterans. Sadly, 21 of them have now died, with five known to be still alive, with the status of one veteran being unknown. These veterans appear to be dying of diseases that are common in our society, although the small number restricts the ability to observe increases in death from some causes associated with radiation, such as leukaemia. By the time that the last of these veterans dies, my Department has calculated that their average life span will have been at least 70 years of age, which is not noticeably different to the Australian male population born prior to 1920. Given that this group of Prisoners of War has not shown marked health effects, there appears limited benefit in studying BCOF veterans.

I might add that this matter has been extensively reviewed by the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA). This body of experts has concluded that the effects on human health from radiation at Hiroshima and Nagasaki were restricted to those who were at the bomb sites within seven days of the actual explosion. The earliest Australian BCOF troops did not enter the area until February of 1946, by which time the best scientific advice is that the levels of radiation had returned to essentially background levels.
(b) Yes. Numerous representations have been received from individuals and organisations representing BCOF veterans requesting such a study.

(c) No. The health status of personnel who participated in the mustard gas trials in North Queensland during 1944 is not being directly examined, and there is no immediate intention to undertake such a study. My Department regularly reviews the literature associated with mustard gas. A broad range of conditions, such as lung and throat cancers, are already accepted as possibly due to exposure to mustard gas. Due to this recognition, claims for compensation for these conditions have been accepted by the Repatriation Commission since 1945.
(2) The situation of widows who remarried prior to 1984 is well known to the veteran community. Any decision to vary the existing arrangements would be made by the Government in a Budget context.

(3) No. The only general "concern" that the Queensland State Office of my Department is aware of in the past 12 months has been the motion raised at the State Congress of the Returned & Services League in August 1998. The motion which was moved by Rockhampton Sub-Branch read:

para.inline: "That the Federal Government is asked to explain what reductions have taken place in staffing in the Department of Veterans' Affairs since it took office."

answer.para: The motion was lost on the floor of the Congress.

Since 1996, there have been a number of important changes in the way the Queensland State Office of my Department delivers services. The Health Insurance Commission is now responsible for the payment of treatment accounts. Information technology and voice services have been contracted to IBM Global Services Australia. The Defence Service Homes subsidy function has been consolidated in Victoria. Single Point of Contact processing has been introduced in the income support areas so that veterans and their spouses deal with just one person for all changes that affect their pension.

Staffing reductions have not affected the collective performance of the Queensland State Office of my Department against the national performance targets of the Corporate Plan. In fact, performance outcomes are particularly sound and in some areas are ahead of the national figures. This has been achieved by the development of better and more efficient levels of service for veterans and war widows.

The Veterans' Affairs Network (VAN) has been expanded throughout regional Queensland with offices opened in Maroochydore (August 1997) and Toowoomba (April 1998). In addition, contracts for agents in Rockhampton, Emerald and Roma to deliver services on behalf of my Department have been let and business commenced on 4 May 1998. In addition, my Department is training agents under the Queensland Government Agents Program (QGAP) with a view to delivering services to the veteran community through another 50 sites in rural and remote areas of Queensland. Training QGAP agents has continued at every opportunity pending the completion of formal arrangements with the 50 sites throughout Queensland.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1107 (Hansard , 13 May 1998, p.2786) which stated that the Area by Area employment declaration form (EDF) best practice examinations identified a total of some 517 cancellations as having been inappropriately recorded:
(1) What is the total number of cases examined in the Area by Area EDF best practice survey.
(2) What percentage of all cases examined as part of the Area by Area best practice examinations were identified as incorrectly recorded.
(3) What was the nature of misrecording of review activities identified in the Area by Area EDF best practice examinations.

(4) Can a breakdown be provided of the 517 cancellations inappropriately recorded in the Area by Area EDF best practice examinations, detailing how each of these cases was recorded and how each should have been recorded.
(5) Have Area by Area best practice examinations been undertaken for any other review activities other than EDF; if so, what were the findings of any such activities.
(6) What percentage of the recording of cancellations of any such review activities was found to be incorrect.
(7) What was the total number of cases examined in any such review activities.
(8) What was the total number of cases found to be recorded incorrectly for any such review activities.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The 517 cancellations identified in the answer (No 1107) of 13 May 1998 were part of a review of 5,679 EDF matches re-examined in the Area by Area best practice reviews.

(2) and (3) The primary intention of the Area By Area reviews was to identify where best practices were being followed by the different Customer Service Centres (CSCs) conducting EDF reviews, rather than a traditional audit. This being the case, the application of a broad `incorrectly recorded' outcome measure is not appropriate as the findings of the individual surveys are, to a degree, subjective. The general nature of the suggested procedural and recording shortcomings identified by the surveys is consistent with the breakdown outlined below in the answer to Question (4). Statistically valid national outcomes cannot be drawn from the aggregation below of the individual results of the various Area by Area best practice surveys.
(4) A breakdown of the previously identified 517 cancellation cases is as follows:
58 Customer surrendered benefit greater than one month after EDF review contact letter was sent out.
101 Customer failed to lodge benefit continuation form (SU19) after EDF selection but prior to review contact letter being sent out.
60 Cancellation more appropriately linked to some non-income related event (eg. marriage or death of customer).
7 Customer failed to lodge cyclic review after EDF selection but prior to EDF review letter being sent out.
12 Customer previously advised of return to work.
36 Cancellation more appropriately attributed to a review category other than EDF.
27 Payment previously identified as suspended pending cancellation.
156 Customer surrendered benefit payment after EDF selection, but prior to review contact letter being sent out.
10 Documentation on system insufficient to verify result.
9 Customer advised full-time study resumed.
3 Payment reduced rather than cancelled.
5 Customer transferred interstate.
12 Incorrect interpretation of policy.
8 Customer transferred to another payment type.
12 Breach penalty imposed rather than cancelled.
1 Incorrect cancellation code used.

While all of the above cases were originally recorded as cancellations linked to EDF match selections, the best practice reviews proposed to the various Area offices amendments to their CSCs records to ensure that the resultant cancellations and reductions were attributed to the most appropriate initiating causes. Where these proposed amendments were accepted by the Area administrations, the review results were amended and staff advised of the correct procedures to be followed in the future. That said, it should be noted that, while in the context of the EDF best practice surveys the above results were deemed to be inappropriately recorded, the cancellation of the payment to the customer remains quite valid.

To clarify this, the issue is how results have been recorded on the National Selective Review System (NSRS), not on the payment systems ie. there is no suggestion that any incorrect adverse action has been taken against customers as a result of the EDF review activity. What is at issue essentially is whether cancellations which actually occurred have been claimed to be the result of an EDF review when they were not, and whether cancellations have been claimed on NSRS when the decision on the customer's payment was actually, for example, a rate reduction or a transfer to another payment.
(5), (6), (7) and (8) Area by Area best practice examinations have not been undertaken in respect of any review activities other than for EDF.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What savings were achieved by the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 scheme between the commencement of the Act and 11 November 1998.
(2) What proportion of this saving was from: (a) fraud; (b) overpayments, which were not fraudulent; and (c) other reasons (please specify).
(3) What savings have been achieved in the past 2 years, as set out in the second reading speech to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill 1998.
(4) What other fraud control mechanisms are in place within the department.
(5) How many misuses of tax file numbers have occurred.
(6) What savings have been achieved by the Australian Taxation Office from tax fraud between the commencement of the scheme and 11 November 1998.

(7) With respect to the claims made in the second reading speech to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill 1998 of future savings of $560 million, what proportion of this saving will be from; (a) fraud; (b) overpayments, which are not fraudulent; and (c) other reasons (please specify).
(8) What are the Government's projected savings from tax fraud over the same period as set out in part (7) of the question.
(9) Will tax file numbers be provided to any person as part of an outsourcing agreement.
(10) Will tax file numbers be provided to any other person outside the Government and the Commonwealth.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is not possible to provide data to 11 November 1998. However, the savings achieved by the Data matching Program from commencement of operations in April 1991 to 30 October 1998 are $919.3 million.

(2) (a) It is not possible to identify what proportion of Data-matching Program savings was as a result of detecting fraud. There were, however, 1,083 successful prosecutions with a debt value of $12.3 million, as a result of the Data-matching Program in the period 1 July 1996 to 11 November 1998. System restrictions mean that it is not possible to retrieve data for the preceding years. It is important to note that, due to the high cost of preparing prosecutions, only the more serious cases of fraud are referred for possible prosecution action. It is therefore incorrect to suggest that the incidence of fraud is limited to these 1,083 cases.
(b) It is not possible to identify the proportion of savings due to recovery of debts which did not involve fraud.
(c) For social security payments, the proportion of savings resulting from other reasons from April 1991 to 31 October 1998 was:

. rate reductions/cancellations-45.8%; cancellations for failing to provide a tax file number- 23.8%; debts recovered from customers who had failed to provide tax file numbers—0.4%; and debts from following up incorrect customer information (Personal Identity Discrepancies)—0.8%

It is important to appreciate that administrative errors are not a significant proportion of all incorrect payments. Surveys by Centrelink show that less than 5% of all recoverable debts are caused by administrative error.
(3) The savings for the Data-matching Program for all agencies from 1996 to 1998 were $377.3 million.

(4) Key components of fraud control are prevention, detection and deterrence. To enable the detection of incorrect payments, Centrelink has a number of mechanisms and procedures in place. These include:
• reviews based on customer characteristics, random samples and duration on payment;
• identity fraud checking; and

• data matching with identity, income or other information held electronically by other organisations. The most significant of these, other than matching under the Data-marching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, which saved $ 1 95 million in social security payments in 1997-98 is matching with Employment Declaration Form data supplied by the ATO, which saved $255.8 million in social security payments in 1997-98.

(5) It is not possible to determine the number of misuses of tax file numbers that have occurred, however the Data-matching Program as well as the Accelerated Claimant Matching process, enables the identification of tax file numbers that have been recorded for more than one person or that have been recorded against a different name to that held on the Tax Office system.

The majority of these Personal Identity Discrepancies (PIDs) have been found to be the inadvertent use by a customer of the tax file number of another member of their family (usually their partner's). These are corrected after contact with the customer. Further details of this process can be found in the Data-matching Program—Report on Progress—October 1995.
For cases where the tax file number belongs to an unrelated person, Centrelink liaises with the ATO to correct the tax file number information.'

(6) This question would more correctly be answered by the Australian Taxation Office, however the ATO has attributed raising $10.8 million in debit assessments to the Data-matching Program. The ATO's participation in the Program has principally been one of supplying data to the Data Matching Agency.

The principal benefit to the ATO from the Program has been the improved voluntary compliance by clients of assistance agencies and the improved quality of client data made possible through actioning discrepancies of personal identity data The ATO also uses a range of other methods, including internal matching, to detect tax fraud.
(7) (a) It is not possible to estimate the percentage of future savings directly attributable to fraud for the reasons outlined previously.
(b) For social security payments, the proportion of estimated future savings resulting from debts from January 1999 to 30 June 2002 is 34.2%.
(c) For social security payments, the estimated proportion of savings resulting for other reasons for January 1999 to 30 June 2002 is:
. rate reductions/cancellations-50.8%; cancellations for failing to provide a tax file number- 14.4%; and debts from following up Personal Identity Discrepancies—0.7%.
(8) This question would more correctly be answered by the Australian Taxation Office, however no projections have been made of tax fraud savings from the Data-matching Program.
(9) There are no plans to provide tax file numbers to any person as part of an outsourcing agreement.
(10) There are no plans to provide tax file numbers to any other person outside the Government and the Commonwealth.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation: See and Avoid Principle Report
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 183)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that: (a) in 1991, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) published a research report entitled, Limitations of the see-and-avoid principle: and (b) the report concluded that: (i) `the see-and-avoid principle in the absence of traffic alerts is subject to serious limitation' and (ii) unnalerted see-and-avoid has a `limited place as a last resort means of traffic separation at low closing speeds [and is] completely unsuitable as a primary separation method for scheduled services'.
(2) Is the Minister aware that BASI repeated this warning in the BASI `Asia-Pacific Air Safety Magazine', dated September 1998, in its article entitled, `Traffic separation in Class G airspace'.

(3) Did the Minister seek advice from BASI about the limitation of `see-and-avoid' and how this impacted on the Class G airspace arrangements; if so, when was that advice sought; if not, will that advice now be sought.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes
(2) Yes

(3) It is not my role to determine what airspace and procedures are safe. That is a matter for the experts. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA), which had responsibility for the Class G airspace demonstration, does not completely concur with all of BASI's recommendations in the report Limitations of the See-and-Avoid Principle.
There were six recommendations included in the BASI report and CASA's responses are as follows:

Recommendation 1: "That CAA should take into account the limitations of see-and-avoid when planning and managing airspace and should ensure that unnalerted see-and-avoid is never the sole means of separation for aircraft providing scheduled services".
CASA Response: Firstly, we will be using our existing cost benefit formula (which is based on the proven FAA Formula) to mandate Class D airspace where traffic densities require.

CASA also proposes a complete package to address this important issue. Unfortunately, unnalerted see-and-avoid cannot be eliminated entirely, as even if primary and secondary radar, Class A airspace, mandatory radio, TCAS and transponders were deployed there can always be a time, because of human factors or technical breakdown, that unnalerted see-and-avoid becomes the primary means of separation.

The CASA proposal is to do everything we can, while still allocating the safety dollars effectively, to reduce the chance of unnalerted see-and-avoid being the primary means of separation, whilst at the same time educating pilots on how they can improve their scan to improve the effectiveness of both alerted and unnalerted see-and-avoid.

In relation to our package to improve the availability of alerted see-and-avoid, we have proposed to the airlines that in future, all airports serviced by scheduled services of over 10 passengers must have third party confirmation that the radio is on frequency. This will reduce the chance of an airline aircraft being on the wrong frequency or the speaker being deselected. We are also encouraging the fitment of Aerodrome Frequency Response Units which will operate 24 hours per day and reduce the chance of unnalerted see-and-avoid. We are proposing to increase the number of recommended calls at non-tower aerodromes to seven, following the USA procedure . This will greatly assist alerted see-and-avoid.

In order to reduce the necessity to rely on see-and-avoid, we will be training VFR pilots to remain clear of areas of IFR traffic density, such as IFR air routes or IFR approach paths. These will be marked on maps in future. In relation t o IFR aircraft, we will be training pilots to follow a recommendation to fly 1MV to the right of track when flying on a marked air route between navigational aids or reporting points when the airway is used for two-way traffic.
In places where a tower is not cost effective and that have RPT services of over 10 passengers, we will have mandatory procedures in relation to alerting.

Recommendation 2: "In light of the serious limitations of the see-and-avoid concept, CAA should continue to closely monitor the implementation of TCAS in the US and should consider the system for Australia".
CASA Response: Agreed and will be introduced where cost effective.
Recommendation 3: "The CAA should ensure that pilots are trained in effective traffic scans"
CASA Response: Agreed and CASA will continue to emphasise that see-and-avoid is a key factor in collision avoidance and pilots should be vigilant.
Recommendation 4: "The CAA should require white strobes rather than red rotating beacons to assist visibility when aircraft appear against dark backgrounds".

CASA Response: CASA feels that rotating beacons and strobe lights should be used whenever an aircraft i s airborne or is taking off, landing, or taxying or being towed (including temporarily stopped while being towed) on an active runway. Pilots are not always able to assess when the display of these lights is effective, so CASA recommends their use on every flight.
Recommendation 5: "The CAA should ensure that pilots are aware of the physiological and psychological limitations of the visual system".

Recommendation 6: "Pilots should recognise that they cannot rely entirely on vision to avoid collisions. Consequently, they should attempt to obtain all available traffic information, whether from Air Traffic Services or a listening watch, to enable them to conduct a directed traffic search".

CASA Response: CASA agrees with both the above recommendations. However, CASA believes that the limitations have been promoted to the extent that benefits of the visual system may have become seriously discounted. As a consequence, CASA will continue to emphasise the requirement to be vigilant.

In summary, recommendations 2,3 5 and 6 have been classified by the Bureau as CLOSED- ACCEPTED, which means that the Bureau accepts the response without qualification. BASI sought and has received further clarification of the responses from CASA regarding recommendations 1 and 4. BASI has classified these responses as PARTIALLY ACCEPTED and is continuing to negotiate with CASA aspects of those two recommendations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: Given that the Australian population of the dugong is listed in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), which permits controlled trade, and given that all other populations of dugong are listed in Appendix I, which prohibits trade completely:

(1) With reference to a formal proposal which has been submitted to the department by the Humane Society International urging the Government to nominate the Australian population of the dugong for an Appendix I listing in CITES: does the Minister intend to list the dugong population in Appendix I; if not, why not.

(2) What investigative work has been carried out by Australian authorities to determine the extent of illegal trade in Australian dugong meat between North Queensland, Torres Strait, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia.
(3) Can copies of any reports be provided.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A decision has not yet been taken as to whether a proposal to nominate the Australian population of the dugong to Appendix I should be made. I would anticipate receiving advice from my Department in the near future on whether a proposal should be developed.
My Department is awaiting comments from State and Commonwealth Government agencies, and industry, conservation and professional organisations on the proposal prior to providing me with its advice.

(2) My Department has made inquiries with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA), the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service on this issue.

The Torres Strait is subject to the Torres Strait Treaty between Australia and Papua New Guinea. The provisions of this Treaty (for continued traditional interaction between the people of Torres Strait and the people of Papua New Guinea) is recognised in the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 which implements the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species in Australia.

Torres Strait Islanders are involved in the development of the management regulations for dugongs and other marine species and actively support enforcement. AFMA and the Queensland Boating and Fisheries Patrol have officers based in Torres Strait who regularly work in all the communities. I am advised they have not received reports of the sale of dugong meat, either domestically or in the traditional trading that occurs with Papua New Guinea. I am also advised that in the Torres Strait there is no trading of any kind with Indonesia.
Torres Strait Islanders have recently commenced developing community-based management plans for dugong hunting in order to further protect dugong stocks.
None of the other agencies contacted have any additional information on this issue.
(3) There are no specific reports available relating to illegal trade in dugong meat.

Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: 1 (a) The Maritime Industry Finance Company Limited (MIFCo) is responsible for making redun dancy related payments, when it is authorised by the Commonwealth to do so, and for deciding the amount of the redundancy related payment which should be offered and made to a redundant employee.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister tor Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Barbara Preston report for the Australian Council of Deans of Education dated 11 November 1998, which shows that from 1999 to 2004 there will be a severe shortage of teachers:
(1) Does the Minister accept those projections; if not why not; if so, how is the Federal Government planning to alleviate this shortfall.
(2) Do the department's projections indicate a shortfall of teachers in regional, rural and remote areas; if so, can details be provided.
(3) (a) What measures are being taken by each state government to encourage the recruitment of teachers; and (b) can details be provided.
(4) What inter-governmental mechanisms are in place to ensure that sufficient teacher graduates are available to meet enrolment demands.

(5) (a) Are teachers currently being offered any incentives to teach in country areas; (b) would the Minister consider dropping Higher Education contribution Scheme (HECS) fees for teachers and/or teachers who opt to commit to teaching in a rural area; and (c) would the Minister consider dropping up front and HECS fees for teachers returning to university.
(6) Have any studies been commissioned to determine why enrolments in teacher training have fallen; if so, can details be provided.
(7) Will medium-to long-term planning be implemented in teacher training programs in order to avoid destabilising structural changes such as those in the early nineties.
(8) Would the Minister consider dropping HECS fees for students who undertake studies in mathematics and science education.
(9) Have studies been commissioned to determine the availability or otherwise of teachers from overseas; if so can a copy be provided.
(10) What effect will the youth allowance legislation have on demand for teachers in 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003 and 2004.
(11) Was an agreement reached with the states on how this demand would be met; if so can copies of such agreements be provided.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The report by Barbara Preston for the Australian Council of Deans of Education Teacher supply and demand to 2004 (1998 update) itself acknowledges the difficulties in making projections of teacher supply and demand. On page 3 it states "What are provided are projections, based on expected future values for many of the relevant variables. The actual outcomes may be quite different—because of actions of stakeholders such as universities and school authorities, and because of the general uncertainty inherent in such labour market projections". This report is the fifth in a series dealing with teacher demand and these reports have demonstrated this inherent uncertainty by consistently overstating the future demand for teachers. The projections have also been challenged by the major employers of teachers, that is the States and Territories. The balance of evidence suggests that predictions of a widespread shortage of teachers are overstated.

(2) The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs publication Skills in Australia—Trends and Shortages states that "Recruitment difficulties are more pronounced in some rural and remote locations". These projections are not broken down by individual region. A copy of this document has been provided separately for the honourable Senator.

(3) Such recruitment difficulties as exist are not common across all States and Territories and priorities for recruitment also vary across the States and Territories. These are matters for teacher employers and the Commonwealth does not hold information on any individual State and Territory initiatives to recruit teachers.

(4) The Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs has established arrangements to monitor teacher supply and demand and the Conference of Education Systems Chief Executive Officers has arranged for the first report on this to be prepared for the Council. The Council has also established a Teacher Recruitment Taskforce which is oversighting market research into and the development of a market strategy which can be adapted by individual states and Territories to suit local needs

(5) (a)The employment of teachers in country areas is the responsibility of State and Territory authorities responsible for schools. The Government believes that the States and Territories are best able to determine local work force needs and to design targeted programs which direct public subsidies to ensuring those needs are met. It is understood that some States and Territories are targeting recruitment for country areas but the Commonwealth does not hold details of State and Territory initiatives.

(b) With regard to the proposal that HECS charges should be reduced for teachers and/or teachers who opt to commit to teaching in a rural area, it should be emphasised that the Commonwealth already makes a significant contribution to the tuition of students enrolled in HECS liable places in higher education institutions including teachers. On average, students in publicly funded places contribute 37 per cent of the cost of their tuition. The Commonwealth pays the remainder. The Commonwealth also bears the cost of the interest rate subsidy which is provided through the interest free HECS loan and of unrepaid debt. The proposal would substantially increase the cost to the Commonwealth when the Commonwealth contribution is already substantial.
(c) As indicated in the response to part (b), the Commonwealth already makes a substantial contribution to the tuition costs of teachers.
(6) Available data show that initial teacher education enrolments have remained relatively stable since 1991.

(7) Strategic planning in disciplines is a matter for individual institutions. However, teacher education is discussed at Joint Planning Committee meetings with States and Territories and reviewed in the educational profiles meetings held each year with the universities

(8) As indicated in the response to Question 5 (b) students enrolled in a HECS liable place at a higher education institution, including those undertaking mathematics and science education, contribute only part of the cost of their tuition. The Commonwealth contributes the remainder. The proposal to drop HECS contributions for these students would substantially increase the cost to the Commonwealth when the Commonwealth's contribution is already substantial.
(9) The Commonwealth has not commissioned any studies to determine the availability of teachers from overseas.

(10) It is expected that some 8 200 young people may return to school on a national basis in 1999 as a result of the introduction of the Youth Allowance education and training requirements which will come into effect on 1 January l999. It is not possible to convert this to a number of teachers by dividing by the average pupil teacher ratio as some commentators have suggested because the flow will not be uniform across all schools. To assist schools to address the needs of these students the Commonwealth Government has introduced the $22.6 million Full Service Schools initiative. The initiative provides assistance to schools to undertake a range of activities including the employment of specialist teachers or counsellors and the provision of professional development for teachers and other staff.
(11) The Commonwealth has not sought to impose any conditions on or reach any agreements with the States as to the employment of teachers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: What study has been done, information gathered, or evidence obtained to show that the increased rate of various forms of cancer in Australians is not related to exposure to, or consumption of, fluorides.

Senator Herron

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is currently reviewing its 1991 publication, The Effectiveness of Water Fluoridation. The publication, based on a study undertaken in 1989—1991, reported that the weight of evidence establishing a link between fluoridation of the public water supply and an increased risk of cancer, was not convincing.

As part of the current review, the issue of possible carcinogenicity relating to fluoride exposure is being considered. Fluoride intake from other discretionary sources such as toothpaste, tablets, gels and mouth washes is also being considered.
