talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 15 December 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) On how many occasions since March 1996 has Australia advised its trading partners of the outbreak of an economically important disease, or the presence of a pest, that may present a danger; and (b) were these declarations made under the provisions of the World Trade Organisation agreement; if so, under what provisions were these declarations made; if not, what was the legal basis for these declarations.
(2) (a) When was each outbreak detected; (b) what was the nature of the outbreak; and (c) when did Australia notify its trading partners of the outbreak.
(3) If trade was suspended: (a) was the suspension imposed by Australia or by importing countries; and (b) how long was each suspension in place.
(4) What process was followed while the suspension was in place to satisfy importing countries that the disease or pest no longer presented a risk.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Since March 1996 there have been seventeen (17) disease and/or pest incidents considered to be sufficiently significant to warrant international notification by Australia.

(b) Australia has certain notification obligations stemming from the provisions of agreements reached at the conclusion to the Uruguay round of trade negotiations. These notification obligations arise under the Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) Agreement administered by the World Trade Organisation (WTO) which encourages WTO member countries to harmonise standards in line with recommendations and guidelines (including notification requirements, if any) of specified international health organisations, specifically:
. the Office International des Epizooties (OIE, the World Organisation for Animal Health);

- under Article 1.2.0.3 of the OIE International Animal Health Code member countries are to notify OIE of occurrences or re-occurrences of specified diseases (List A diseases), and new findings for all animal diseases that are of exceptional epidemiological significance to other countries;
- similarly, Article 1.2.0.3 of the OIE International Aquatic Animal Health Code defines Australia's obligations to notify on specific aquatic animal diseases;
. the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC, regionally managed through APPPC, the Asia and Pacific Plant Protection Commission);

- Article VII of the IPPC requires reporting periodically to the FAO, of the existence, outbreak and spread of economically important pests of plant and plant products which may be of immediate or potential danger; and

. the Codex Alimentarius Commission, a subsidiary body of the FAO and the World Health Organisation, which develops food standards and recommends International Codes of Hygienic/Technological Practices.

Australia has endeavoured to meet both the letter and the spirit of these obligations however, notification provisions under these guidelines are not standard across all agricultural sectors, for example;
. notification of animal or aquatic animal incidents where required is usually through the OIE, whereas

. formal notification of Plant pests/diseases is now either direct to trading partners or through organisations such as the Pacific Plant Protection Organisation (PPPO), which is the FAO sanctioned body for the region;
- such notification was previously through the FAO World Reporting Service and the FAO Plant Protection Bulletin, however these services were disbanded two years ago;
- Australia reports annually to the PPPO and once every two years to APPPC on the plant pest status of Australia and these reports constitute official FAO notification.

Trading partners are advised of diseases and pests that could effect bilateral trade of Australian plants, animals or fish, and their products as a matter of course. Timely reporting of accurate information and consultation between scientific peers can also be important in managing incidents and minimising market impacts. This occurs both formally and informally, through various mechanisms including overseas posts, direct contact and through the PROMED reporting system on the internet.
(2) With regard to seventeen specific incidents and notifications since March 1996, I provide the following information:

entry.para: Sorghum Ergot signs were detected and subsequently confirmed on several properties in Gatton and Darling Downs, QLD.
April 1996 trading partners, then PPPO for annual report
A new Lyssavirus was detected from sick flying foxes near Ballina, NSW.
Equine Morbillivirus (now known as Hendra virus) was discovered in flying foxes near Brisbane
Lupin Anthracnose was detected on properties in Geraldton WA and subsequently found at several locations in SA, Vic And NSW.
Unusual outbreaks of Anthrax in northern Victoria.
A Paramyxovirus was isolated in August 1997 after investigations into reproductive difficulties, initially thought to be an endemic virus, in a Menangle NSW piggery.
Detection of Fireblight signs in Melbourne Royal Botanic Garden cotoneaster and other.
May 1997 trading partners, then PPPO for annual report
Black Sigatoka was detected on one Daintree organic banana property, QLD.
July 1997 trading partners, then PPPO for annual report
Panama Disease was detected in a Berry Springs banana property.
Philippine Fruit Fly adult flies were detected in early warning traps in Darwin, NT.
December 1997 trading partners, then PPPO for annual report
An outbreak of highly pathogenic Avian Influenza occurred in three poultry farms in close proximity near Tamworth, NSW.
Detection of Pine Aphid on a radiata pine in the ACT with subsequent detection of aphids widespread in ACT, NSW, Vic and QLD.
Two human cases of Japanese Encephalitis (JE) were diagnosed in Torres Strait and Cape York Peninsular in QLD. Sub-clinical infection of pigs was demonstrated.
Adult Ash Whitefly was detected on pomegranates in Adelaide, SA with subsequent detection on several other hosts in Vic, NSW and ACT.
May 1998 trading partners, then PPPO for annual report
Sugarcane Smut was detected on several cane properties in the Ord River Irrigation Area, WA.
Virulent Newcastle Disease occurred in three associated poultry farms, two in western Sydney and one at Rylstone, NSW.
A Pilchard mortality event associated with a pilchard herpesvirus commenced off the coast of SA then moved into WA and Vic.

answer.para: Note: Concurrent with the above notifications individual trading partners were advised of relevant incidents as a matter of routine.
(3) For the purpose of this response, trade suspension is taken to mean Australia wide suspension of trade for a product or group of products.

Any general suspension imposed by Australia on exports is usually for a very short period while the incident is scoped and suitable, usually localised quarantine restrictions are determined and implemented. Where practical the aim is to eliminate the pest or disease, and regain the international `status' that previously applied.

While Australia may impose export suspensions or other trade limiting measures, other countries may also impose restrictions on that trade. This occurs particularly where the relevant disease or pest is significant to that country. There are numerous instances where individual countries have imposed restrictions on specific products, or products from specific States or regions, or have required additional certifications. For example, after the September 1995 Equine Morbillivirus incident, Thailand instigated bans on the import of horses from Australia from 30 November 1995 until a new protocol was negotiated and imports recommenced on 30 May 1996. Another example followed the March 1998 Japanese Encephalitis (JE) incident, where revised requirements were imposed by China, Vanuatu, New Caledonia and Argentina relating to certification that JE was not present on the property of origin or within 200 km of that property. While such restrictions can be very significant to individuals or companies, they are not considered to constitute a suspension of trade.
Of the seventeen incidents notified and listed above, three resulted in suspension of Australia's trade, and a fourth (1998 Pilchard mortality) is included because it is in progress.

Black Sigatoka in July 1997 resulted in the suspension by Australia of trade in organic bananas. At the time trade involved only small volumes of product to Japan. Trade was suspended at the request of industry. This has been the only suspension relating to a plant pest/disease incursion in the period in question. At the instigation of the Banana Industry Protection Board (an industry body) the affected plantation was destroyed to prevent further disease spread. Industry has not sought to have trade resumed.

The highly pathogenic Avian Influenza incident in November 1997 resulted in an interim short-term suspension on the export of all poultry and poultry products by the Australian Quarantine and inspection Service until the extent of the disease and appropriate controls on the movement of product were implemented. Such action ensured that international obligations were met and reinforced the technical trust and cooperation established with most export markets. Animal health authorities from thirty two countries subsequently imposed additional conditions/bans on the imports of poultry and poultry products. These varied according to the products and regions, from the whole of Australia to only the area under quarantine. The restrictions were progressively removed over periods that varied from weeks to one year. The last restrictions were removed on 14 December 1998.

Similarly, the September 1998 Newcastle disease incident also resulted in an interim short-term suspension by Australia and the implementation of appropriate controls on movement of the product. It also resulted in restrictions being imposed by some thirty five trading partners. Restrictions to varying degrees are still in place for more than twenty countries.

Although Pilchard mortality in October 1998 did not result in trade suspension, Commonwealth and State Fisheries authorities have implemented commercial pilchard fisheries bans in areas of mortality. These have typically lasted for approximately four weeks each (the duration of mortality plus a `safety' period).

(4) Satisfying importing countries that the disease or pest no longer presents a risk can be a long and involved process. Countries that may have imposed restrictions on Australian imports usually require evidence of appropriate control measures before they will consider resumption of trade. The notification process, combined with appropriate general and/or bilateral updates is of assistance in this process.

Once specific and scientifically sound local quarantine restrictions/controls are implemented, and/or eradication is effected, detailed advice is provided to the concerned countries. A proactive and iterative negotiation process is undertaken aimed at reducing and ultimately removing these restrictions. This usually involves input from all parties including industry, State and Commonwealth authorities.
Regarding the July 1997 Black Sigatoka suspension, industry has not sought to have trade resumed.

The November 1997 pathogenic Avian Influenza and the September 1998 Newcastle disease incidents were managed under the nationally agreed AUSVETPLAN procedures for disease containment, eradication, and surveillance. These procedures ensure that Australia can meet OIE requirements to regain regional and subsequently country disease freedom. The latter incident is still under active management.

The 1998 pilchard mortality incidents are being managed through restrictions on fishing imposed by South Australian, Victorian, Western Australian and New South Wales Fisheries Authorities in consultation with the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 15 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What process is followed by the Australian Government to suspend imports from a country where a disease, or pest, that presents an economic risk has been detected.
(2) Is the authority to suspend imports found in the provisions of the Quarantine Act 1908 (the Act); if so, what are the relevant provisions.
(3) What provisions of the Act were applied in the suspension of imports of fresh fruit from the United States of America announced on 29 October 1998 by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister.

(4) Did the Government seek legal advice about the suspension prior to, or following, the imposition of the suspension; if so: (a) who sought the legal advice; (b) why was the advice sought; and (c) what was the nature of the advice received.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The process followed by the Australian Government in suspending imports from a country where a disease, or pest, that presents an economic risk has been detected is for the Director of Quarantine, or his or her delegate, to take a decision to refuse to grant import permits to products from that country which are hosts to the pest (or disease) or to amend the conditions for the granting of an import permit in order to mitigate the risk (for example, sourcing product from areas free of the pest). Without an import permit, such product cannot enter Australia.

Product en route at the time such a decision is made is held in quarantine when it arrives in Australia. In addition, an interrogation of the AQIS Export Management System can be used to track any imports which have already entered the country and which may need further investigation.

(2) The authority to suspend imports is found in the Quarantine Proclamation 1998. The mechanism by which suspension is achieved is through the Director of Quarantine deciding, pursuant to his discretion under section 70 of the Quarantine Proclamation, not to grant a permit for the importation of goods which present an unacceptable level of quarantine risk. The Quarantine Proclamation derives its authority from section 13 of the Quarantine Act 1908.

(3) A delegate of the Director of Quarantine exercised his/her power under sections 64 and 70 of the Quarantine Proclamation 1998 not to grant a permit for the importation of fresh fruit from the United States.

(4) The Government did not seek legal advice prior to, or following, the imposition of the suspension of imports of fresh fruit from the United States announced by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister on 29 October 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 December 1998:

question.para: With reference to the process of `refining' the reserve boundaries for the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement (RFA), an area in the Great Western Tiers (Kooparoona Niara) of about 200 hectares was removed from reservation and made available for logging, the precise location is at Bessels Road, near Meander, the centroid of the area is about 6600E, 7950N:
(1) On what date was the change made.
(2) How is the new boundary different from the boundary agreed between the Prime Minister and the Premier at the RFA signing.
(3) What other changes have occurred.
(4) Does this mean that the boundaries agreed between the Prime Minister and the Premier at the RFA signing are not fixed.
(5) Were about 3 500 hectares of pre-existing formal reserves added to the RFA Western Tiers conservation area to make the figure look good.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Determination of the precise boundaries at the 1:25,000 scale is an ongoing process involving State agencies and is conducted in accordance with the provisions of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) process.
(2) Clause 5 of Schedule 6 of the Tasmanian RFA provides that:

"Areas shown have been identified as indicative areas at a map scale of 1:100,000 held as an electronic data layer by the State. The State will finalise boundaries of 1:25,000 maps to enable gazettal, refer to clause 24 of the agreement. Finalisation will include identifying best management boundaries. Wherever possible, these will follow easily identifiable features, including natural or ecological boundaries. Finalisation will also consider field verification of values being protected, and appropriate boundaries mapped to protect the identified values."

I am advised that the 1:100,000 scale RFA boundary in this section of the Tiers did not follow any specific feature. It included an area which field verification showed had been heavily disturbed by clearfell logging and regeneration a few years ago. The area does not contain any values in the form of under-reserved forest communities, old growth forest, or wilderness which would be necessary for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system (CAR). Forest roads had been constructed into the area and a productive young regrowth forest established following the logging. The Tasmanian Government decided to exclude this small peripheral area from the final reserve boundaries due to its low conservation value and in recognition of its developed nature. It represents a very small proportion of the 22, 500 ha in the new Great Western Tiers Conservation Area approved by the Tasmanian Parliament. I am advised that in other parts of the Tiers, boundaries were adjusted to add areas outside of the indicative RFA boundary line

(3) Any boundary adjustments have been made in accordance with clause 5 of Attachment 6 of the RFA which sets out the process to be followed by the Tasmanian Government in finalising boundaries and have been incorporated into the Regional Forest Agreement (Land Classification) Act 1998.

(4) The RFA signed in November 1997 contained a large-scale map of intended boundaries of the proposed reserves. Precise boundaries were required to be finalised based on reserve management principles as agreed in clause 5 of Attachment 6 of the RFA.
(5) Any areas of existing or new reserves forming part of the CAR reserve system are counted towards achieving a JANIS outcome.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 6 January 1999:

question.para: (1) In what water systems in Australia is acrolein used, for example, stock, domestic and irrigation.
(2) How much acrolein is used in them and what are the minimum and maximum parts per million levels.
(3) What are the risks to humans from using acrolein in their environment.
(4) Are there any known side effects to using acrolein or being in the vicinity of it.
(5) Is it a fact that irrigation districts are the most likely places for exposure.

(6) (a) What is a safe level of exposure to acrolein; (b) how much at the highest rates possible is in any irrigation channel being treated; (c) how close do some people in the community live to poisoned channels, in metres or kilometres; and (d) how does the acrolein leave the water to make it safe.
(7) Does smelling the chemical over a given period of time pose any risk to the public.
(8) Is it used in built up areas.
(9) Is it a fact that it has been used in the manufacturing of chemical weapons.
(1) (a) Is it a fact that many people living in rental accommodation on farming properties are not informed of its use and still draw water; and (b) are they in danger from doing so.
(11) Is it publicly known that rates as high as 150 times or more than the accepted exposure rate could be in channel irrigation within 20 feet of homes.
(12) Has anyone ever been poisoned by acrolein in Australia or has the system ever made a mistake in taking proper precautions to protect the public or individuals from its effects.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Acrolein is used for the control of submerged weeds in flowing water. It is used primarily in irrigation channels, but in some circumstances it is also used by water supply authorities in sewerage water lagoons and domestic water supplies in rural areas. Acrolein is used only in New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia.

(2) Varying concentrations are applied, up to a maximum of 15 parts per million, depending on the water flow and weed infestation characteristics. In some areas the concentration is between 0.5 and 1 part per million. The specialised application equipment used ensures that a metered dose not exceeding 15 parts per million is applied.

(3) Acrolein is injected under water directly from steel containers, and users are required to use extensive protective equipment. In addition, only certified operators (usually employees of water supply authorities) are allowed to apply acrolein, so there is minimal risk to humans. The risks from using acrolein include inhalation and eye and skin irritation, but such effects would only occur if correct procedures were not followed or by accident.

(4) Appropriate studies of acrolein have produced no evidence for carcinogenicity, reproductive toxicity, developmental toxicity or genotoxicity. The main side effects from exposure to acrolein are upper respiratory tract irritation and congestion and eye irritation.

(5) The major use of acrolein is in irrigation districts, so they are the most likely places for exposure. Acrolein is commonly only used in the main irrigation supply channels, and water is contained within these channels during and after treatment. Treated water is then released into on-farm channels after sufficient time has passed for the acrolein to dissipate. The method of application ensures that acrolein is not exposed to air except in the event of an accident.

Acrolein is transported by road, mainly by the distributing company. It is stored, transported and handled under Dangerous Goods, Pesticides and Occupational Health and Safety legislation. Dangerous Goods procedures include avoidance of urban areas during transport.

Acrolein is produced as a by-product in combustion of several substances, and sources of exposure include emissions from internal combustion engines, cigarette smoke, incomplete combustion of wood and plastics, and overheating of fat. Acrolein is a significant industrial chemical, so people working in those industries which use acrolein may also be exposed.

(6) (a) The Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) for acrolein is 0.0005 mg/kg/day and a daily oral intake of 0.035 mg/day for a 70 kilogram individual should not present an appreciable health risk. Using the above ADI, a health guideline value of 0.002 mg/L has been set, to allow for accidental contamination of drinking water. The safe level of exposure to acrolein in the atmosphere is 0.1 part per million.

In the MRL Standard, published by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, acrolein used for aquatic weed control is listed as a substance where Maximum Residue Limits (MRLs) are not necessary. Such an entry is made for a chemical where residues do not or should not occur in foods or animal feeds; or where the residues are identical to or indistinguishable from natural food components; or are otherwise of no toxicological significance.
Current guidelines indicate that ambient levels of acrolein in aquatic ecosystems should not exceed 0.0002 mg/L.

(b) The quantity of acrolein in a channel depends on the volume of the channel and/or the duration of injection. The concentration is maintained at or below 15 parts per million by matching application rates to measured channel flows.
(c) Farmhouses may be located within 30 metres and townships within 1 kilometre of treated irrigation channels.

(d) Acrolein reacts with water to form a different chemical substance. Studies of acrolein in channels have shown it has a half life of between 3 and 10 hours, depending on water pH and temperature conditions. Other processes that dissipate acrolein in water are volatilisation, adsorption and dilution.

(7) Given the volatile nature of acrolein, it becomes present at some level in the air following application in channels. Depending on the concentration of acrolein in air, inhalation exposure may lead to a health risk in humans. Indications from State authorities are that the levels of acrolein present in air following application in water do not reach hazardous levels.
(8) Authorities in all States in which acrolein is used have advised that acrolein is not used in built up areas.

(9) Acrolein was introduced by the French in January 1916 for use in filling gas munitions, namely grenades and shells. However, because of the inherent instability of acrolein, it was not a successful chemical warfare agent in World War I, and was therefore not widely used. With the introduction of much more suitable agents (eg mustard and subsequently nerve agents), it is highly improbable that acrolein is being used, or will ever be used again, in the manufacture of chemical weapons or in chemical warfare.

(10) (a) In States where acrolein is used, adjoining landholders, water users and nearby residents are notified 7 days prior to application of acrolein. While notification methods vary slightly between the States, in most cases people are notified individually. Additional methods of notification used include notices in local newspapers, radio announcements and erection of signs.

(b) In addition to the measures described in (a) above, in most situations treated water is not released from channels for 48 hours. This means that acrolein will have dissipated before the treated water is used, so water users would not be in danger.
(11) I have no knowledge of the occurrence of exposure to acrolein in channel irrigation at levels as high as 150 times the accepted exposure rate.

(12) In Western Australia in 1996 an individual complained of itchy eyes and skin after ignoring warning signs and swimming in a channel. There are no other recorded cases of acrolein poisoning, or complaints about acrolein, in Australia.

It is possible that poisonings have occurred from exposure to acrolein emitted from sources other than herbicides. One reported case involved an artist who was overcome by gas while ironing artwork. The gas was determined to have contained acrolein.
There have been no reported cases of failures in the registration or control of use systems for acrolein in Australia.
